description: We have been working with Private sector (Pick n Pay retail company), who is one of the large grocery retailers in the country. They are helping us test an Enterprise Supplier Development experiment for small scale producers We also worked with the Small Enterprise Development Company (SEDCO) who are a state owned enterprise and a lead partner for this learning cycle.  We also worked with the Eswatini water and Agricultural Development Enterprise (ESWADE) who provide technical support for the pilot on agro-processing of honey aimed at understanding the technical barriers to trade that affect local small scale produceres.

We worked with Ministry of Commerce, SME unit, Ministry of Agriculture (Home economics department) to develop a pilot for agro processing of Cayenne Pepper to test the viability of moving local farmers higher up the value chain and developing local standards for this.

We work with various stakeholders. In this case, we have established a UNDP/Government/Civil Society, Innovation Ecosystem partnership to help address flooding challenges. Regarding civil society organizations and the innovation ecosystem, we are collaborating with organizations such as Zero Inondation, Keur Thiossane (Fab Lab), Inond'actions, URBASEN, GRET, OpenStreetMap Senegal, CONCREE Civil society organizations and the innovation ecosystem play a crucial role in the flooding arena. Because of their proximity to the affected populations, they are able to co-construct strategies with them in order to better understand the issues related to floods and to act accordingly to limit the risks. A partnership with these groups of actors could prove decisive in the search for effective and innovative solutions.

We have worked with companies such as GEOMATICA. Collaboration will be open to other companies, including start-ups that have been selected as part of the Water Innovation Challenge.

Since the AFA is a single point integration solution that seeks  to avail supply chain financing for the horticulture value chain, it was key to establish partnership across the value chain from production ( horticulture farmers), extension services, government (Ministry of Agriculture) logistics, cold storage, off-takers and financial institutions (bank and non-bank). The concept of single point integration requires all these key actors to act as one through the platform. This then describes the full spectrum of the partnership

The academic partner was SIMAD university to which we have an ongoing partnership agreement. Our partnership gave us access to a large sample of students from SIMAD’s entrepreneurship training program. The students were either owners of informal business or early stage entrepreneur’s all trying to build their networks and knowledge in business. This was the ground for us to conduct surveys, focus group discussion and direct interviews.
The Behavioural Insights Team (BIT) on a year long behavioural insights capacity building exercise along with 10 Arab States country offices.
MoJ was the main partner working with us and using their HQ to conduct the testing.
Their mandate is with Civil Registry and engaged in many of the initiatives including Mobile Justice vehicle.
This partner was spearheading digitalization in the country specifically in the justice sector and provided insights.

Veneactiva: Non-profit organization that works towards formalization and wellbeing of the Venezuelan migrant and refugee population in Peru. Together with Veneactiva we carried out a design research process of focus groups, in-depth interviews and sensemaking sessions. Their participation was key to build user profiles, as well as testing the pilot’s contents. Through Veneactiva and its allies’ social media channels we spread the word about the project and ensured greater participation through a social movement logic.

Universidad de Piura/Kaman incubator: The Universidad de Piura, specifically their Kaman incubator, joined the matchmaking event as part of CREANDO, where migrant entrepreneurs could choose to join incubators or business associations to continue strengthening their entrepreneurial skills.

1. Yape/BCP: Yape (a digital wallet) initially presented their services to CREANDO participants but, with the Lab’s support and mandate to work with unusual partners, the CO has further developed this relationship and in 2023 the full suite of personal and SME finance courses created by the BCP (the bank that owns Yape) will be accessible to all participants in the Innova tu Mercado and CREANDO participants. / 2. Learning by Helping: Developed a series of “social innovation snacks” (20’ long) as part of the CREANDO digital content for migrant entrepreneurs. These snacks complemented the content from other partners and particularly the Accelerator Lab sessions on business tools. / 3. Internet para Todos (IpT) https://ipt.pe/. A joint initiative between BID, CAF, Telefónica and Facebook in order to shorten the digital divide in Latin America by bringing connectivity to rural and highly complex geographic areas.

Prime Minister's Office - Digitalization Secretariat: We worked with PCM, the Digitalization Secretariat of the Prime Minister's Office, to develop the design of the DRA and DPGA. We exchanged experiences with other countries and we were able to showcase Peru’s digital transformation experience at the UNGA 77 Side Event: The Future of Digital Cooperation on 21 Sep 2022. Even though we had to postpone the implementation of the DRA and DPGA, we have centered on building a strong relationship with the team at PCM for future opportunities and further deployment of UNDP digital initiatives.

Our partnership with local governments focuses on using sensemaking and systems thinking to address municipal challenges. In San Miguelito, a joint exercise with UNDP senior management and municipal directors demonstrated the value of a systemic approach and showed how social cohesion can drive transformation. We are now expanding this approach to 2-3 other municipalities, fostering inter-municipal collaboration on shared challenges like waste management.

links.target: Colombian Association of Financial Innovation and Technology Companies (Colombia Fintech)
description:
The partnership brought together UNDP Colombia—through the Accelerator Lab and the Office’s Chief Economist—with non-traditional private sector actors, including fintechs, insurers, impact investors, cooperatives and development finance institutions, alongside government counterparts. UNDP acted as a neutral convener and facilitator, creating a trusted space for dialogue and co-creation around the Financing for Development agenda.

Through iterative engagement, the partnership enabled actors with diverse incentives and perspectives to align around a shared narrative, generate collective insights, and translate them into strategic inputs that informed Colombia’s positioning for the Sevilla Conference and strengthened longer-term ecosystem collaboration.

links.target: National Women Entrepreneur Council (NWEC), under the aegis of the Ministry of Gender Equality and Family Welfare
description: The UNDP Accelerator Lab initiated this collaboration with the National Women Entrepreneur Council (NWEC) to mobilise women to become entrepreneurs in the green economy, particularly in building and running agri-enterprises. This collaboration put forward the expertise and experience of the NWEC as well as the National Women Council (NWC) and other stakeholders, to better prepare, coach and mentor women to develop their ideas into income-generating activities. This collaboration has allowed UNDP to co-design learning sessions with the NWEC and the NWC team to better support the skills and knowledge development of the council through structured and tailored interventions that focused on a human-centered design approach, leverage the UNDP Accelerator Lab methodologies and approach to future visioning and build the capacity of participants to use innovative tools in public sector delivery and public sector innovation.

Mosul Space Organization: The UNDP Accelerator Lab Iraq with a generous fund from UNDP - Recovery Solution and Human Mobility in Crisis Bureau worked with the Mosul Space Organization to support boosting the entrepreneurial ecosystem in the newly liberated areas through developing an online platform “Startups Bus” to gather all the entrepreneurship ecosystem activities in one place, and visualize a database of service providers in Mosul. Hence, supporting bringing different technical and business communities together in one place. Throughout the process a collection of data from various sources will be achieved and visualized on the platform. (This solutions is still under experimentation) Knowledge Gate Organization: The UNDP-AccLab in Iraq and this organization focused on  to a sustainable and innovative economy in Iraq through innovatively analyzing the challenges faced by the private sector, newly startups, and SMEs in Iraq during COVID-19 to gather most common systemic problems and allow a group of youth to find innovative solutions in a shape of a business model that is to be studied and rated by the companies, each company adopts one project that matches its scope and helps it operate better and sustain. During the Q3 of 2022, the two partners implemented two phases of initiatives , the first one prepared the needed assessment with several companies in the Private sector in Iraq, and then  developed the report that led the partners to implement the interactive workshop for 3 days, and used system thinking, future thinking , and design thinking.

Asiacell and Codelab:The UNDP AccLab implemented an Innovation Mission with CodeLab company and Asiacell Telecommunication Company within three months in Q4 of 2022. This mission is  centered around supporting the community's local solutions to implement and grow their solutions through integrating the power of Artificial Intelligence to their projects in order to be responsive to the emerging development needs in the country.  The uniqueness of this completion were: Experimented a new approach in Iraq of mixing the Human Centered Design approach (Design Thinking Methodology) with the Artificial Intelligence to come up with innovative, sustainable, efficient, and human centered business projects. The Competition responded to the emergent needs of digitalization and put Iraqi businesses in the front seat of development. Creating partnerships between big private sector companies (e.g. Asiacell) and startups (e.g. CodeLab). Phase One (Call for Application): +450 applicants from business owners in Iraq applied to participate in this competition through a 2 weeks online campaign on social media. Only 30 participants were selected. Phase Two (Training): intensive training to the participants to integrate the power of Artificial Intelligence and Human Centered Approach to their projects. Phase Three (Mentorship): Nine innovative projects were filtered from the previous stages and took 5 weeks of intensive mentorship from specialists in different fields in order to develop their projects (Finance, Marketing, AI, business development, etc.) Phase Four ( Final Competition): Seven innovative projects where they presented their ideas in front of 300 public audience and 5 judges. North Hands: The  UNDP AccLab in Iraq supported one of the local solutions owned by Iraqi innovators initiative and North Hand Company to develop  The Startups and SMEs Management in Crisis Times online Course.  The aim of this course is to improve business skills necessary for SMEs operating the post-crises scene. The final innovative local solution should support the training of key aspects of post-crises business management to Iraqi startups and SMEs, specifically focusing on sharing tools and alternatives to minimize business disruption post the crises and providing operational and financial management advice. This interventions implemented through three stages as below: Developed curriculum for the course focusing on the five objectives identified above. Tested the developed curriculum material before the production of the final course through performing a workshop for startups and SMEs which will cover key aspects of post-covid business management. Developed the final course and recorded it to be posted on the UNDP InPoint platform. Origins Program by Doinc Company: Origins program is implemented and owned by a local startup called Doinc for Business Development and Consultation. The UNDP Accelerator Lab Iraq supported the implementation of this program on different levels.  First intervention was through the designing phase, and the second intervention was through sharing the knowledge and experience.  This program aims to put participants in the driver’s seat on a safe, fun and well-designed learning journey. The destination of their journey is to enter the private sector as entry level employees or as interns by developing their knowledge, skills and attitudes.

links.target: Ministry of Higher Education and Scientific Research (MoHESR)
description: Ministry of Higher Education and Scientific Research (MoHESR): During Q2 the UNDP-AccLab in Iraq implemented two experimentation workshops with MoHESR to test the developed Blended Learning Teaching Methods curriculum with trainers and professors from 35 Iraqi universities. links.target: Office for Common Affairs of Bosnia and Herzegovina
description: Our leading partner was the Office for Common Affairs of Bosnia and Herzegovina state institutions. Due to the nature of their work, this Office has a significant and diverse procurement portfolio. We overviewed products and services the Office regularly procured and analyzed their greening potential. We developed recommendations for green procurement criteria for all products and services groups identified, including the options for alternative greening approaches (e.g. how to minimize procurement of paper with some procedural measures). The final result was creating a standard tender dossier with green criteria (the tender qualification and award criteria and technical specifications) for three products and services identified as priority ones: printing and photocopying paper, electrical energy and IT equipment.     We also collaborated with the Slovenian Directorate for Public Procurement to exchange their experiences, impediments, and solutions for green procurement with procurement specialists from Bosnia and Herzegovina.

links.target: Centro de Ayuda Mutua “Salud para Todos” (CAMSAT)
description: For the case studies, we made contact with civil society organizations active in the territories where we identified positive deviance. They provided interviews and insight about what explains the positive deviance. These included, Centro de Ayuda Mutua “Salud para Todos” (CAMSAT), Coordinadora de Organizaciones del Bañado Tacumbú, local neighborhood committes (comisiones vecinales),  Organización de Desarrollo Rural de Mandu´ara (ODRAM), and local health councils (Consejos de Salud).   Fort the third stage of the Positive Deviance project, which is connected also with the citizen engagement challenge, we worked with Tesaireka Paraguay, a network of organizations that work specifically on promoting Primary Health Care as a right, working closely with Family Health Units across several regions of Paraguay.   In Wendá, we have partenered with a local grassroot producers’ fair in San Juan Nepomuceno, a city in the rural department of Caazapa, and with Foundation AMORMAR, for implementing the experiment on the field. Moreover, in the flexible manufacturing experimental intervention of this project, we engaged also with a local association of textile workshops.

links.target: Ministry of Public Health and Social Welfare
description: Our main institutional partner for the positive deviance project has been the Ministry of Public Health and Social Welfare. They provided interviews, administrative data, and professional opinion to define the case selection criteria and to identify the case studies of positive deviance, as well as institutional access to the research sites.   As we progressively broadened this challenge to include our work with ENI in Wendá, we also partnered with the Presidential Delivery Unit (UGPR). Through them, we articulated efforts with the Social Development Ministry (MDS), The Presidential Technical Unit of the Social Cabinet (UTGS), and the Municipality of San Juan Nepomuceno, to implement an experimental intervention that tested the prototype of a new public food security social program, based on food stamps that were interchangeable at a local grassroot producer’s fair. Likewise, we partnered with the National Service for Professional Promotion (SNPP) and the Municipality of Yaguaron, to test the prototype of public training program, contextualized to the needs that we had identified on a cluster of textile workshops. Synergies between this second intervention allowed us to articulate efforts and incorporate elements on it that could address also the challenge of employment formalization though a productivity increase that could lead to a higher capacity to formalize employees.

ISTU (Salvadoran Institute of Tourism). ISTU is the entity that manages 3 Natural Parks and 11 Water Parks, including Balboa Park. ISTU provided logistical support and supported the whole process within the Park.

Returning Point (https://tackapovratka.rs/en/) is a program that fosters circular migration and assists in the return of highly-qualified expatriates while channelling active communication between Serbia and its diaspora around the world. It is a hub that establishes connections between local talent and diaspora initiatives that are focused on transformation, research, science and culture. This initiative was launched with the support of Serbian Entrepreneurs (San Francisco, USA), the Science and Technology Park Belgrade, and the Office of the Prime Minister of Serbia, and underwent incubation and capacity building within the UNDP Initiation Plan in close collaboration with Accelerator Lab and SDGs Integration Plan within UNDP Serbia. United National Development Program has been one of the key partners and supporters since January 2020. Since January 2020, the United Nations Development Program has been one of the most important partners and supporters. AccLab worked closely with Returning Point primarily in the areas of initiating and co-designing program activities, as well as supervising the quality of their work and ensuring that their activities are designed to be learning opportunities. 




Some of the products of our collaboration that we could highlight :

Guides for returnees (https://tackapovratka.rs/vodiczapovratnike/), a digital platform for Serbian diaspora and returnees, made using design thinking methodology

Carta Serbica (https://tackapovratka.rs/en/projekti/carta-serbica/), a program intended for individuals from the Serbian diaspora who do not hold Serbian citizenship and are interested in living, working or retiring in Serbia.

Mentorship programme (https://tackapovratka.rs/en/programi/mentorstvo/), a mentorship program that connects and provides support to Serbian returnees by matching them with mentors  

Infostud job-matching platform (https://tackapovratka.rs/en/programi/radi/), collaboration with the largest job platform in Serbia. A platform shows current job opportunities suitable for people with international experience so that our diaspora and potential returnees have a better understanding what are their options. 

Work from Home, work from Serbia (https://tackapovratka.rs/destinacija-srbija/), an experiment that we ran during COVID-19, presenting Serbia as a remote work-friendly destination.




Digital Serbia Initiative and BelgradeGets.Digital 

Another key partner that helped us with exploratory entry points of the Depopulation portfolio was Digital Serbia Initiative “DSI”. (https://www.dsi.rs/en/). The mission of this NGO is to build a robust, globally competitive digital economy in Serbia. 




Together with them, we launched the initiative called BelgradeGets.Digital Initiative (https://belgradegets.digital/) was envisioned as a spinoff of the Lab that will carry forward the work on (foreign) digital nomads and digital professionals in Serbia. BelgradeGets.Digital Initiative attracting digital professionals to Serbia was mapped through our solution mapping exercise. AccLab identified the local website (MoveToBelgrade.com), which we assisted in rebranding to BelgradeGetsDiital and becoming the main online destination for promoting Belgrade as an attractive destination for the lifestyle and work of digital nomads and other digital professionals from around the world. 




For the Depopulation Portfolio, digital nomads and digital professionals were identified as positive deviance that we wanted to explore as a trend. Throughout our work, besides launching the Webportal, together with DSI we:

launched “Digital Nomad Scanner" (https://undp.medium.com/understanding-digital-nomads-38f71678e884  and https://www.undp.org/serbia/publications/digital-nomads-scanner), 

run an exercise in mapping potential infrastructure needs throughout the country in areas with the potential for the formation of the digital nomad and digital professional communities with the goal of improving the offering to both foreign and domestic digital professionals, and 

led a vaccination programme for the digital nomads/professionals that we supported (https://belgradegets.digital/nomad-life-back/) and executed as an experiment that formed typical online sales techniques (e.g. lead generation) that we borrowed from the business and IT world.

Throughout our work on depopulation, we organized a Depopulation Data Challenge as an open call for multidisciplinary teams to develop various digital/data-driven depopulation solutions. This collaboration was initiated and orchestrated by Accelerator Lab.

https://lab.undp.org.rs/depopulation-data-challenge/ 

For the HDR work, Accelerator Lab had seven professors from Vienna University, and the University of Belgrade, working on the NHDR, as well as from the Institute of Social Sciences and many others working on depopulation for the HDR project (Studio, Data challenge, etc.)

Together, we conducted a number of experiments, including the exploration of new migration patterns, collaboration with Returning Point to provide new employment opportunities for the Serbian diaspora and returnees, further workforce diaspora segmentation, exploratory work on the topic of women in STEM, etc.

links.target: Integration Unit, Team for Population Issues, Prime Minister’s Office
description:
Prime Minister’s Office - Integration Unit, Team for Population Issues

Accelerator Lab aided in the formation of a new three-person team of senior advisors within the Office of the Prime Minister, who started working in February 2022 to lead the development of the program with government partners and operationalize the portfolio.

This new team uses all of the HDR's findings and the Lab's previous work in this field as a basis for its work. In addition, this PMO team will continue to collaborate with the UNDP on the operationalization and localization of the portfolio's large-scale projects, through the PIF (Portfolio Initiation Framework) process. 




Ministry of Family Welfare and Demography and local mayors across the country

In order to localize the work on the Depopulation portfolio, we collaborate closely with the Ministry of Family Welfare and Demography, as well as with the mayor's offices of ten medium-sized towns/local municipalities located across the country. 




Public consultations and NHDR
We co-hosted five public consultations with the Ministry of Labor, Employment, Veterans and Social Affairs and SASA for the wider group of stakeholders (https://www.sanu.ac.rs/en/) and with the leading national counterpart Office of the Prime Minister. The aims of these consultations were:

1. To achieve a common understanding (framing) of population dynamics including depopulation: inevitable, but not catastrophic; actions required regarding human capital, not solely fertility, etc.

2. To involve the government of Serbia in the drafting of the NHDR through comments and inputs.

3. To identify potential partners for the depopulation fund and future activities.

The main participants of these consultations were: Line ministries (at the level of head of units and assistant ministers), public institutes, academia, civil society and media

In order to document the thematic areas and develop the problem statements in blue economy and nature-based solutions, we worked with 3 environmental organizations and associations in different islands: Projeto VITO in Fogo Island, Projeto Biodiversidade in Sal and Bioesfera 1 in São Vicente Island. They provided sector field/local knowledge and documentation. In later phases, they provided mentors and coachers to help teams develop their solutions and jury members in some cases to help evaluate the final solutions presented.   In São Vicente Island, we worked with a fishermen community association of São Pedro, that help involve fishermen, divers and fishmongers in the challenge with one team, developing a solution for the community.

3 universities were involved in the Blue Hack 2022 with the purpose of obtaining expertise and information about the blue economy sector, mobilizing participants and providing mentors and speakers for the workshops: E-Mar (Escola do Mar), UTA (University of the Atlantic) and UNI-CV (University of Cabo Verde).   E-Mar is a university especially created in São Vicente to provide courses, graduation and investigation in maritime economy and sea sciences. They were with the organization of the Ocean Week 2022 and provided us the venue and logistic support in São Vicente’s hackathon edition.   They also promoted the participation of their students (in last year of graduation) in the initiative.

For the inclusive recycling project, our private sector partners included Soluciones Ecológicas, a recycling and sustainable waste management company and the local Coca-Cola Bottling company, They co-designed the prototype of the waste collection service offered by members of the San Francisco Neighborhood recyclers’ association and built upon both our relationship with waste pickers and our participatory mapping processes to decide pilot neighborhoods for their implementation.  We were also able to integrate learning into this action by designing and implementing its impact evaluation.

With the aim of bringing organizations closer to these institutions and their current support programs

The Tavarandu Program, with the local government training and the Citizen Laboratories, take place this year 2023 in two districts: Natalio, in Itapúa department, and Pilar, in Ñeembucu department. Both interventions were developed in partnership with the local government from the beginning. The local government created a group to take the leadership and coordination of the process.

The Tavarandu Program, with the local government training and the Citizen Laboratories, take place this year 2023 in two districts: Natalio, in Itapúa department, and Pilar, in Ñeembucu department. Both interventions were developed in partnership with the local government from the beginning. The local government created a group to take the leadership and coordination of the process.

The experiment of Public Goods Trust was developed with teachers and students from public schools in Natalio. To do so, the experiment was first presented to the territorial authorities of the Ministry of Education, the supervisors, and with their approval, the experiment was then presented to the school's directors and coordinated with them.

For the experiment of Public Goods, we invited students at the National University of Itapua to volunteer in facilitating the training and the game with the school students that participated. The volunteers had training first themselves, to better comprehend the game and its dynamics, and to apply it then with the students.

Mentu was hired to implement the Tavarandu project in its second edition. Based on the lesson learned from the first edition in 2022, and working closely with the AccLab, Mentu designed the syllabus for the training, implemented the trainings to the local government, designed the toolkits for the Citizen Laboratories and help the local group from the local government to facilitate and implement the activities with the citizens.

The Station Foundation for Entrepreneurship: The UNDP-AccLab worked with the Station For Entrepreneurship to implement Raa’idat Competition that aims to empower women entrepreneurs, in the ideation stage, to structure their businesses. Mosul Space Organization: The UNDP Accelerator Lab Iraq with a generous fund from UNDP - Recovery Solution and Human Mobility in Crisis Bureau worked with the Mosul Space Organization to support boosting the entrepreneurial ecosystem in the newly liberated areas through developing an online platform “Startups Bus” to gather all the entrepreneurship ecosystem activities in one place, and visualize a database of service providers in Mosul. Hence, supporting bringing different technical and business communities together in one place. Throughout the process a collection of data from various sources will be achieved and visualized on the platform. Science Camp for Youth Development: The UNDP-AccLab in Iraq partnered with Science Camp Organization for Youth  to scale up the local solution, SC Face Shields. This innovative Face Shield locally made from PET transparent film, it covers the full face (eyes, nose, mouth, and skin) to provide 80% face protection from the Coronavirus (estimated protection 80%), with the face mask, the protection becomes 98%. This face shield is important for the individuals working on the field and cannot stay at home due to the nature of their jobs, such as medical staff, delivery services, cash points and more. The Face Shields were used by various partners within the public and private sectors in Iraq. The local solution’s owner could successfully distribute 3500 phase shields to 7 Iraqi Hospitals through Iraqi Association for Medical Research Studies. Deutsche Gesellschaft für Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ): The UNDPAccLab cooperated with GIZ, Ministry of Higher Education and Scientific Research, and various stakeholders of the entrepreneurial ecosystem in Iraq to produce the first Business Development Manual for Iraqi students to be taught at the Career Development Centers of 35 Iraqi Public Universities. The fruitful results of the work led to producing, testing and launching  a 10 chapters manual that guides students on how to start their own entrepreneurial enterprises. TED Non Profit Foundation : The UNDP Acclab in Iraq worked with the TED foundation team and Global Acclab teams on developing the Arabic version and testing out an easy-to-use browser extension that helps anyone flag malicious content online.

links.target: College of Agriculture, University of Basrah (UoB)
description: College of Agriculture - University of Basrah (UoB): The UNDP Accelerator Lab Iraq worked with College of Agriculture - UoB and used innovative methodologies (Design Thinking, Future thinking, and value chain) with the professors and students to come up with graduation projects that fit the market need. The result of the work was presented in the first international conference related to sustainable agriculture, titled “International Conference Sustainable Agriculture and its Role in Economic and Human Development”.  Cambridge University: Support the research of students at Cambridge University on “renewable energy solutions for closing the gender and digital divides. LSE University: The UNDP-AccLab supported LSE researchers to explore potential policy solutions and contextual characteristics that promote grassroots innovation in developing countries, Iraq.

Dar Alhiraf: The UNDP-Accelerator Lab in Iraq is working with Dar Alhiraf to support the concept of Green Economy through sensing, exploring, and mapping innovative local solutions to facilitate the shift of Iraq’s economy toward sustainability. Hence, the lab worked to financially, technically and logistically support a group of talented women mainly vulnerable women to design and produce creative Eco-bags. These eco-bags feature authentic Iraqi designs with a mix of traditional and modern motifs to spread Mesopotamian culture to the world, encourage the public to preserve the environment and bring awareness to participating in our society. These women produced more than 3000 eco-bags and promoted them through bakeries and supermarkets to initiate a positive behavioral change towards the consumption of environmentally friendly products. Asiacell: The UNDP Accelerator Lab is working with Asiacell company based on the signed MOU between the two parties to support young entrepreneurs and start-ups in developing innovative solutions to local challenges. Hence, the AccLab worked to get a fund from Asiacell to conduct a big competition in 2022 to support innovation among youth. Computic: The AccLab support in ideating innovative tech-based solutions for the current context in Iraq in cooperation with Computic Private sector Company. Computic has CS50x-Iraq, a technology-based local initiatives and groups to design digital solutions for a set of worth-solving problems within country development challenges. The UNDP Accelerator Lab worked with CS50x-Iraq to sense and explore country development challenges and provide an intensive Human-User Centered Design Training that helped raise levels of local technological solutions ideated by participants of CS50x-Iraq. This resulted in producing  innovation of 11 tech-based projects by over 20 Iraqi youth.

links.target: Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs (MoLSA)
description: Ministry of Higher Education and Scientific Research: the UNDP started the Blended-Learning Initiative along with the Ministry of Higher Education and Scientific Research (MoHESR). The Initiative mainly aims to support the upskilling of higher educational professionals to be able to adopt new technological skills to influence positively on the students skills,  and produce the first of its kind Blended LEarning Teaching Methods Curriculum that incorporates blended learning into designing and writing of the new teaching methods curriculum for 35 Iraqi universities. Now the UNDPAccLab in Iraq and MoHESR are finalizing the prototype of 56 modules for seven specializations for the Blended LEarning Teaching Methods Curriculum that should be launched in March 2022. Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs (MoLSA): The UNDP Acclab in Iraq used Behavioral Insights Methodology to identify behavioral nudges that can be used to enhance innovation within Business Incubation Centers inside MoLSA. The AccLab worked for 6 months with the ministry to sense, explore and test potential solutions. The journey led to injecting behavioral change to the entrepreneurs joining the training programs in the Business Incubation Centers, specifically to enrich the ideation stage. The Accalab supported Business Incubation Centers with new methodologies such as System and Future Thinking and tested with the trainers how to embed Design Thinking training manual (Local solution) in their project.

In the beginning of 2022, the Accelerator Lab Guinea Bissau started a learning experience focused on public space, in collaboration with the Municipality of  Bissau, UN Habitat, Lusófona University, and the Architecture School of KTH The Royal Institute of Technology in Stockholm, Sweden. The collaboration is exploring different topics such as the possibility to open an Architecture education in Guinea Bissau to contextualize the build environment from a local and human centered approach, how academia can play a role in generating proposals to improve housing and public space and how maintenance issues can be tackled by a greater involvement of the citizens.

We worked with Balad alkhieer Endowment Foundation which aims to educate society about the concept of humanizing charitable work, social solidarity, entrepreneurship mindset boosting and creates communities that support in tackling local development challenges. As UNDP we are supporting in: Providing expertise and awareness on the Sustainable Development Goals; Exchange experience and knowledge support to enhance the Green Circle project; Providing subject matter experts, where needed, to support in enhancing proposed circles; Connecting to Green Circle’s network; Supporting the Development Trips.  The idea behind Green Circle is to raise awareness on developmental issues as well change the mindsets of communities whether it’s NPOs, Private sectors and others. The Green Circle’s level of engagement does not go deep into the technicalities of the solutions to the issue as they do not want to be similar to an incubator’s function. The purpose is to create a network (circles) of communities interested and passionate about a specific issue and cause to bring them together. This is organized through the online platform but consists of in person meetings and discussions on specific topics.

We been a part of several small activities to support universities in regards to raising awareness on the SDGs as well as promote multi-stakeholder engagement. This includes coordinating and moderating a session during UN Day on "on emerging and innovative approaches of partnerships with Academia"; presenting to Princess Noura University (PNU) Students on how to make a better impact on spreading awareness on the SDGs using different tools; in addition to supporting PNU students who have initiated the Green Circle on Plastic Consumption (which would potentially serve as a pilot in PNU and can be scaled to other universities in the future).
We have gained the interest of Solutions by STC to create the SDGs Innovative Solutions Platform in KSA but have still not managed to secure a governmental partner to proceed.

UNDP with the support of UTTARAN has visited the successful entrepreneurs' shop to understand their certification, branding and online business techniques. Based on that understanding, necessary support has been provided to the selected learners. In consultation with the selected learners, UTTARAN has finalized the branding and packaging strategy for the marginalized and vulnerable dry fish producers. UTTRAN has inserted few hygiene related messages on packaging to draw the attention of the customers and consumers of dry fish. Initially UTTARAN took the initiatives to arrange a suitable place where the producers can produce and package their dry fish products. Youth learners are also encouraged so that they can financially contribute to this business model.

Legal Design Turkey is one of the winners in AccLab Turkey’s Social Innovation Challenge which was launched back in December 2020. Their team consists of legal professionals and designers who, under our guidance,  delivered various visual outputs that will be used to improve project outcomes. Several women's organisations, since women's organisations provide direct support to survivors where the state fails, their perspective had to be incorporated into the design products.

The San Francisco Neighborhood Waste Pickers’ Association has been the main partner in our inclusive recycling learning loop. They participated in a series of workshops to characterize their work and barriers to their productivity, a GPS shadow mapping exercise, and a pilot recycling program designed to provide more personalized recycling collection to households in particular neighborhoods. For the recycling pilot program, Moises Bertoni Foundation was an institutional partner.   We also consulted with domestic worker unions to characterize the barriers to their access to social security.   The Apparel Workshop Association of Yaguaron participated in the characterization process of the clothing cluster and the experiment (randomized control trial) carried out.

For the inclusive recycling project, our private sector partners have been the local CocaCola Bottling company, and the waste management company, Soluciones Ecológicas. They codesinged and executed the recycling collection service with the waste picker association.   For our experiment about domestic workers’s access to social security, we partnered with two financial services cooperatives (COMECIPAR, Cooperativa Universitaria) and a social club (Club Centenario), to identify households with interest and financial capacity to register their workers for social insurance and offer personalized advising to complete the registration process. Signing MOUs with these associations was key for reaching a group of people with socioeconomic possibilities for domestic work formalization.   For an experiment about labor productivity in the garment industry, we collaborated with the Apparel Workshop Association of Yaguaron and employed a large local apparel brand as a consultant to introduce quality management practices and test their effect on productive efficiency.

links.target: Ministry of Labor, Employment, and Social Security (MTESS)
description: The Ministry of Labor, Employment, and Social Security (MTESS) has been our main partner for the learning loops on domestic workers and construction workers. They have provided feedback on the learning methodologies and knowledge products, and validated and contributed to the design of experimental interventions.   For the work on the apparel industry, instructors from the National System for Professional Promotion (SNPP), received training in quality management and performed the monitoring function to measure manufacturing productivity in apparel workshops that participated in our experiment in the manufacturing cluster in the municipality of Yaguaron.   The Municipality of Yaguaron hosted a workshop to disseminate the results of the apparel experiment in which apparel workshop owners helped us interpret the results and propose ways to improve local and national policies as well as their own collaboration in the private sector to develop greater flexibility and competitiveness in their cluster

The recycling project has been carried out in close collaboration with the UNPD Paraguay environment portfolio, as part of the recycling pilot project of the Asuncion Green City of the Americas project. They have co-financed and co-supervised our interventions.   The Participatory Employment Formalization Laboratory has been carried out in collaboration with the ILO’s southern cone social security specialist and in consultation with RBLAC gender specialists. They have provided feedback on the design of the project, the interventions and experiments we have been designing, and the knowledge documents that the learning loops have generated.

KCCA is responsible for the physical planning and operations of the Capital of Uganda Kampala. This includes ensuring that the city has good infrastructure in terms of transportation, waste management as well as maintaining the drainage system in the city among other services. Together with the community, and other stakeholders, we co-created the drainage system with KCCA following the wider Kampala City Drainage master plan.  KCCA approved the designed drainage systems of the 2 zones.

This is charged with the responsibility of coordinating, monitoring, regulating and supervising environmental management in the country.

NEMA spearheads the development of environmental policies, laws, regulations, standards and guidelines; and guides the Government on sound environment management in Uganda. In doing this, NEMA contributes to social-economic development and wise use of natural resources, focusing on providing support to the Government’s main goal of ensuring sustainable development contributing to the National Vision, the National Development Plan (NDP), regional and global commitments including the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).

We are currently working with NEMA to conduct an environmental impact assesment to esure that the designed drainage system of the 2 zones Kiggundu and Sebina are not detrimental to the environment. This is still a work in progress, NEMA is yet to give a verdict on the designed systems before construction begins.

This is the very first unit of leadership in the community. We worked with the Chairpersons of the 2 zones Kiggundu and Sebina who together with their leadership helped to mobilize the community members to participate in this learning cycle. We obtained ethnographic data, and solutions and now going to implement together the construction of the drainage systems using community human resources.

We worked with Mongolian Federation of the Blind as well as Mongolian Association of the Deaf. We learned a lot about the specific needs of people with visual and hearing disabilities. Based on their feedback we adjusted our content, our approaches to reach out to these people, as well as shared our learnings with the working group members to develop the national digital skills framework.

We worked with Mongolian Federation of the Blind as well as Mongolian Association of the Deaf. We learned a lot about the specific needs of people with visual and hearing disabilities. Based on their feedback we adjusted our content, our approaches to reach out to these people, as well as shared our learnings with the working group members to develop the national digital skills framework.

In addition to these two CSOs, we worked with Faro Foundation, which specializes in conducting digital skills training. While their focus was mostly secondary school teachers, during our collaboration, we gained specific learning on delivering skills training to elderly population.

We worked with Whyze LLC for our online campaign, which specializes on media outreach and brand creation. We earned the creative process of developing a brand, as well as other specific details of brans communication.

We worked with E-Mongolia Academy, which is tasked to provide digital skills to various segments of the population. Our experiments fed into their action plan and make course correction into their action plan.

The departmental governments are our key partners.

- We mainly work with the Municipality of Montevideo in a strategic innovation process with the Deep Demo process where we address the complex challenge of garbage.

- With the Municipality of Canelones, we are working in three processes: 1- we are addressing the complex challenge around gastronomy as a vector of social transformation; 2- we are working on the development of an innovation lab; 3- we have implemented an Innovation contest that helped to improve the motivation of employees who work directly with the public.

- With the Municipality of Treinta y Tres, we are working on the development of an Innovation Lab.

Furthermore, we also work with the national government implementing innovation processes. For example, with the INAU (National institution of children and youth in Uruguay), we are working in the development of an innovation contest to improve the motivation of the public employees. 

The ANII (National Agency for Investigation & Innovation), is our partner to develop the innovation contest both in Canelones and INAU.

- With the Municipality of Treinta y Tres, we are working on the development of an Innovation Lab.

Furthermore, we also work with the national government implementing innovation processes. For example, with the INAU (National institution of children and youth in Uruguay), we are working in the development of an innovation contest to improve the motivation of the public employees. 

The ANII (National Agency for Investigation & Innovation), is our partner to develop the innovation contest both in Canelones and INAU.

links.target: Secretaria de Integracion Social – Alcaldía de Bogota (liderazgo)
description:
The collaboration brings together the strategic leadership of the Bogotá City Government, through the Secretaría Distrital de Integración Social (SDIS), the national expertise of Banca de las Oportunidades in financial inclusion, and the innovation and learning capabilities of UNDP’s Accelerator Lab.

This joint effort was established to understand, through evidence and user-centered methodologies, how vulnerable households experience financial and digital services in their daily lives. The three institutions co-designed and implemented an exploratory phase that included focus groups, behavioural insight tools, analysis of user journeys, and the identification of structural tensions between the supply and demand of financial services.

The collaboration allowed each actor to contribute its strengths:

SDIS provided territorial leadership, access to IMG beneficiaries, and integration of findings into the City’s 2026 planning.

Banca de las Oportunidades contributed technical guidance on financial inclusion, insights from the financial sector, and support in validating opportunities with providers.

UNDP Accelerator Lab contributed wih methodological design, behavioural analysis, synthesis of insights.

Together, the partners co-created a shared roadmap and prioritized actions—such as experiential financial education, simplification of digital services, savings, financial education—that will guide the prototyping and implementation phase of Bogotá’s Financial Well-Being Ecosystem.

Coordinate with relevant partners

Ensure the system is aligned with government priorities.
They helped us with access to frequent public transportation users.

The partnership was formalised under a MoU. The MoU The MoU specified two main priority areas of cooperation under this joint effort, including:  

i) Conducting socioeconomic research and strengthening data management and analytics of HDC in alignment with the targets for SDG 11 - Sustainable Cities and Communities.   

ii) Convene and facilitate evidence-based policy-practice exchanges between HDC and regional urban cities to create a learning ecosystem.

MIC is the national-level institution missionally in charge of both industrial and SME policies. Through our partnership with MIC, we established close contact and collaboration with their Entrepreneur Support Centers (CAE), when they are available in the territories where we are implementing our pilots. Within MIC, a particularly relevant partner is DINAEM, the section in charge of SME promotion and support. 

MTESS is our partner in the implementation of continuous improvement programs for garment workshops. Through SNPP and SINAFOCAL, both programs from MTESS that provide professional training to workers, we are able to train workers and owners of garment workshops in specific techniques, such as molding and sewing machines maintenance and adjustment.

The first three municipalities have helped us implement each step of the program for garment workshops. Particularly relevant in the process of surveying local garment workshops and identifying key actors in the local community. Moreover, municipalities also play a role in our data governance model. Because of the sensitivity of the information, we collected in the surveys, data about each workshop is separated from addresses and contact information. The latter is the only part of the data that was handed over to municipalities. Interested parties, people or organizations, who want to get in touch with specific workshops, can then go directly to the local government for contact information, but specific characterization data remains anonymized and aggregated, even if publicly available for research purposes.

In the case of San Lorenzo and the regional Government of Itapua, their role was mainly to articulate local contacts for the two surveys of SMEs we implemented in their territory, which were finalized and socialized this year.

These five companies are taking up the role of becoming the “Lead Companies” that will contribute to the process of developing their “suppliers”, the small garment workshops that we have selected in the three clusters. Lead companies provide a sustained demand for products from their suppliers, while continuous improvements are being implemented.

Each company also participates, to some degree, in this process of implementing improvements, providing technical expertise or anchoring training programs to specific products they demand, although in our case, most of the improvements that were finally designed for the programs are not anchored to specific products from these companies.

links.target: Chamber of Commerce, Industry and Services of Ñeembucu
description:
To implement the “associativity” component of the work in garment workshop clusters, we established alliances with three different associations of garment workshops: (1) The Association of Clothes Manufacturers of Yaguaron, (2) Pre-Cooperative of Associative Work Ñeembucu, and (3) Association of Textile Artisans of Ñeembucu. Through these associations, we are expanding the training offer from the improvement programs to other workshops, while advising its members in ways to improve how they make better use of associativity and collective action.

Entrepreneur Support Centers (CAE) have a governance model where there is a multi-sectorial board of representatives with local territorial presence: there is one representative from the academia, usually the most relevant local public university; one representative from the local government, and one representative from the private sector, usually, chambers of commerce. The guilds we mention here are all related to the three different CAE that we have supported or collaborated with throughout this year. Their involvement in the activities is still incipient, but they are key contacts to the local private sector ecosystems.

We are establishing relationships with civil society organizations working with renewable energy projects in the territories. In some cases, we were able to map solutions with their help. We also talked to organizations that work on open hardware. 

Three of the organizations with which we worked were selected by the campaign “People Powered” (https://www.undp.org/acceleratorlabs/peoplepowered/solutions). These were “Litro de Luz”, “The Green Box”, and “500Rpm”. The first organization uses recycled plastic bottles and locally sourced materials to illuminate homes, businesses, and streets; The Green Box uses allelopathy to keep fruits and vegetables fresh, and 500 Rpm works on cheap wind turbines that can be built and replicated because they are open patent. 

We began to collaborate with an environmental organization called EcoHouse, which showed a great interest in the findings resulting from the mapping of solutions. That's why we have been in contact with them regarding the solutions, aiming to promote new opportunities for networking. Additionally, we will be presenting our findings in a diploma program on renewable energies at a national public university.  

Also, we have maintained preparatory meetings with EcoAndina, an organization based in the northern Andean region of Argentina. This organization aims at the developing of clean energy solutions mainly for the local communities. During these meetings with the EcoAndina team, we have assessed current practices and identified existing gaps related to the implementation of clean energy solutions. These conversations are part of the input we will use for the design of the energy experiment we plan to deploy next year

EAN University: They where an ally in the development of the Collective Intelligence Experiment and we tried to set an experiment with their students, but it did not have enough participants to be carried out.

USAID: Is the initial partner of the project and provided the Lab with the funding for the development of the project.



Vicepresidency of the Republic (Vicepresidencia de la República): As part of the government, in 2021 the entity launched the Productive Inclusion Social Lab (Laboratorio Social de Inclusión Productiva), and its main goal was to focus on citizens in informal labour schemes or informal businesses, to improve the attention provided to them. This was aligned in two policy documents and two laws, related with entrepreneurship, business formalization, and street vendors. For this reason, the Vice-presidency was intendedto be the main beneficiary of this project.



Bogotá’s Economic Development Department (Secretaría Distrital de Desarrollo Económico): Was another ally for the development of the experiments, providing us with the entrepreneurs who participated in the experiments and other logistical assistance necessary to carry them out.


Tax Department (Departamento de Impuestos y Aduanas Nacionales – DIAN): Was one of the institutions that participated in the articulation of institutions and helped providing assistance and talks for the participants of the experiments.



National Retirement Fund (Colpensiones): Also participating giving talks to the participants of the experiments on the benefits of formalizing as individuals and having formal job schemes for employees.

Additionally, they help coordinate our work with other government actors in the state.

links.target: Center for Entrepreneurship and Innovation, Fullbright University Vietnam

The partnership helped support the county government in generating data on water access, levels and use. The county has thus embarked on utilizing the data to make evidence-based decisions on water infrastructure projects, budget allocations and respond to climate-related events.

Through this partnership, NDMA utilized the data generated to influence decision-making within the county steering group comprising the county government, NDMA and civil society partners working within the county to identify non-functional water infrastructure. As a result, one of the partners, World Vision, has put in an investment to repair 4 boreholes which will ultimately serve 1,920 households.

The partnership involved diverse disciplines from the institution supporting the co-design process and field testing. From this we have had research interests spring up and research papers that will be published in the coming year.

Vox Radio is a community radio station and was useful in communicating our work in their radio shows. Community needs picked during co-design sessions, fieldwork and feedback from stakeholders informed their programming.

SunCulture equips farmers with precision irrigation solutions. Insights gained from collaborating with the private sector (SunCulture) during the co-design sessions explored ways the water resource map could enhance livelihoods and economic prospects in arid and semi-arid lands (ASALs). Investments in off-grid solar technology for various water sources emerged as a promising avenue, offering improved community access to reliable water, irrigation, lighting, and mobile charging, thereby generating employment and fostering economic growth.

Un partenaire clé qui a présenté des solutions d'irrigation comme le système ANAROUA et le complexe de magasins de stockage d'oignons à échangeur géothermique.

Le partenariat avec le secteur privé dans le cadre du défi d'apprentissage "Transformer l'agriculture avec l'irrigation Innovante au Niger" a consisté à collaborer avec des entreprises locales innovantes pour développer et promouvoir des technologies d'irrigation adaptées au contexte nigérien. Les entreprises comme Innovatech et IPREN ont été des partenaires clés, apportant des expertises techniques et leurs solutions innovantes, telles que le système d'irrigation ANAROUA et la technologie Smart'O. Ces partenariats ont permis de combiner les ressources et les connaissances du secteur privé avec les besoins des communautés locales, facilitant ainsi l'adoption de nouvelles technologies et contribuant à l'amélioration des pratiques agricoles au Niger.

Ces partenaires ont joué un rôle crucial dans l'innovation et l'expérimentation des nouvelles techniques d'irrigation et de gestion des ressources agricoles au Niger.

Le partenariat avec le secteur privé dans le cadre du défi d'apprentissage "Transformer l'agriculture avec l'irrigation Innovante au Niger" a consisté à collaborer avec des entreprises locales innovantes pour développer et promouvoir des technologies d'irrigation adaptées au contexte nigérien. Les entreprises comme Innovatech et IPREN ont été des partenaires clés, apportant des expertises techniques et leurs solutions innovantes, telles que le système d'irrigation ANAROUA et la technologie Smart'O. Ces partenariats ont permis de combiner les ressources et les connaissances du secteur privé avec les besoins des communautés locales, facilitant ainsi l'adoption de nouvelles technologies et contribuant à l'amélioration des pratiques agricoles au Niger.

The Lab worked most of the time with  exiting National Employer Unions (ECAM & GICAM) to sense the  challenges and opportunities young people face in the Job Market. Basically during workshops, organized meetings or working group sessions.   The lab also worked with Orange digital Centre, a subsidiary of the Orange Cameroon  telecommunications company. Prototyping with youth on innovative projects in waste management, collective intelligence sessions and workshops, including drafting of an MOU to concretise  collaboration.  The Lab also interacted with private start-ups  like JABA SPACE and ACTIVE SPACES for the organization of design thinking workshops.

The Lab collaborated with United Nations Volunteer Programme to engage in a panellist session on the World  Environment Day to share knowledge on "Restoring the Ecosystem in West and Central Africa; How can UN Systems Support Existing Efforts". The lab took this as an opportunity to engage local solution holders addressing climate change issues who shared their experiences with almost over 40 UNV connected from selected West and Central African Countries, and how their solutions actually drive at ecosystem restoration.

We've worked with Agile Development Group which is an impact enterprise using human-centered design to create solutions for people with disabilities. Designing a product requires both in-depth knowledge of the issue your product is solving and engineering practicality. Agile Development Group and other engineering experts joined us to offer a session to help guide participants in the design challenge to ensure their crazy ideas for a better waste bin are feasible in term of material, architecture, and manufacturing technique.

We invited a professor from Royal University of Phnom Penh to be part of the judging panel. His work with informal waste picker mapping is vital for us to understand the relationship between waste in general and the role of informal waste picker.

We worked with a globally recognized NGO (TECHO) to develop an integrated Community Profiling and Solutions Mapping methodology.

We worked with the Higher Education School of Business (ESEN) to test our Accelerator's kit through the Introduction to Innovation course, taught by our Head of Solutions Mapping. The courses' final project was a Solutions Mapping exercise to identify existing grassroots innovations around water and livelihoods and design new business models using such open-source solutions.

We worked with a private data analytics firm (AS Analytics) to codesign an experimental session through an interactive survey and micronarrative inspired by the hero's journey methodology to identify problems and relevant calls to action for different audiences, as well as a Collective Intelligence activity to collect qualitative insights from different demographics around water and livelihoods by collecting stories and memories that were interpreted through illustrated characters. Speech to text tools were also used to analyze participant's perspectives on the subject matter. Also, we worked with a geospatial technology solutions company named ADEVCOM to visualize the community profiling and mapping of solutions related to access and use of water in the coastal area of the Department of La Libertad in El Salvador, through a GIS StoryMap to show the results of the sampling of water in rivers and sea. Additionally and unexpectedly, two large private firms (Ternova Group and Siemens-El Salvador/Mexico) reached the Lab to exchange insights around sustainable businesses that tackled some of the core issues around water access, quality and conservation in El Salvador. What these companies had in common was that both of them were working on intrapreneurship challenges for sustainable businesses.

We were supposed to coordinate with the Presidential Water Commission but it was unexpectedly disbanded and there was no handover of our joint plans to any institution. However, the Ministry of Tourism expressed interest in our water quality storymap and we are in the process of publishing it, including other relevant information for the tourism sector in the Surf City area.

Dans le cadre de l’exécution de son Plan de travail annuel 2022, le Laboratoire d’accélération du PNUD Congo a programmé la conduite d’un cycle d’apprentissage devant aboutir à l’opérationnalisation voire la mise à l’échelle d’une première cohorte de cinq solutions locales innovantes ayant pour certaines déjà fait l’objet d’un processus d’expérimentation. Ces solutions touchent plusieurs domaines, dont l’économie circulaire, l’Agro-business et le numérique à travers les plateformes de vente en ligne des produits de première nécessité. C’est dans ce contexte que le PNUD Congo a signé un contrat avec l’Incubateur et accélérateur d’entreprises KOSALA pour l’accompagnement et l’encadrement de cinq solutions innovantes.

For these cycles we have worked with women leaders and members of 12 Local Development Councils in Estanzuela as well as the leaders from 3 Neighborhood Councils in Zone 5 of Guatemala City.   Humanitarian OpenStreetMap, an international NGO, have supported with the definition of outcomes and related activities in order to perform open mapping data collection on solid residues and waste management.   “Plogging” with civil society participating in the Sweden Embassy stand for waste classification during the City’s Cultural Festival, where the Lab made live demonstrations on how to classify and compost for public audience.

Carnegie Mellon University, U.S. based, supported identifying and performing initial tests (PoC) of analytical methodologies for monitoring environmental policies, through a Capstone project of graduate-level students advised by a faculty member.   Promoting solutions on waste classification and the value for circular economy within the UN Year of Glass 2022, we have engaged with 2 main private universities: Universidad del Valle de Guatemala and Universidad Francisco Marroquín, conducting conferences, open dialogs and recyclethon.

Carnegie Mellon University, U.S. based, supported identifying and performing initial tests (PoC) of analytical methodologies for monitoring environmental policies, through a Capstone project of graduate-level students advised by a faculty member.   Promoting solutions on waste classification and the value for circular economy within the UN Year of Glass 2022, we have engaged with 2 main private universities: Universidad del Valle de Guatemala and Universidad Francisco Marroquín, conducting conferences, open dialogs and recyclethon.

Carnegie Mellon University, U.S. based, supported identifying and performing initial tests (PoC) of analytical methodologies for monitoring environmental policies, through a Capstone project of graduate-level students advised by a faculty member.   Promoting solutions on waste classification and the value for circular economy within the UN Year of Glass 2022, we have engaged with 2 main private universities: Universidad del Valle de Guatemala and Universidad Francisco Marroquín, conducting conferences, open dialogs and recyclethon.

With the processes of Transition Plans we approached the waste collection trucks, known as “yellow trucks”, starting from the owners (who are associated) to conduct local research with the workers, half of them under payroll and the other half under informality and how the system works.   Celebrating the UN Year of Glass 2022, we partnered (without MoU) with Vical, the largest company in the region that processes glass with a 90% rate of recycling as a lead example of circular economy. We conducted diverse process of raising awareness in usage of noble materials that recyclable in a 100%, such as glass, but also the benefits on a more conscious consumption reducing the pollution in our lakes, rivers, and seas.

1.      UNDP Environment Program: a.      Binational Project for the Comprehensive Management of the Motagua River Basin (MARN-UNDP-GEF), including waste management. b.      Along with Small Grants Program – GEF, in the process of accelerating solutions on human waste management towards circular economy sub-products. 2.      UNDP Governance and Democracy for Peace Program: a.      Technical course for Governance and Public Innovation including waste management participatory process to co-design Transition Plan towards waste public services improvement.   3.      UNDP HQ ITM, where GIS specialists advised and supported the activities for accessing high-resolution satellite imagery and using analytical method for identifying unmanaged waste sites and monitoring environmental policies. 4.      Small Grants Program to accelerate grassroot solution after Innovation Challenge, focused on human waste transformation into forest bio-fertilizer based on circular economy principles.

links.target: National Secretariat of Science and Technology
description: 1.A. Ministry of Environment and Natural Resources (MARN)             a) Binational Project for the Management of the Motagua River Basin (MARN-UNDP-GEF)             b) Department for Solid Waste Management (national) 1.B. Municipality of Guatemala and its environment and waste management departments, Ideathon participation and validation of the real prototype 1.C. Municipality of Estanzuela, prioritized territory for Motagua River Watershed: waste characterization and transition plan for AG 164-2021 1.D. Municipality of Pachalum, prioritized territory for Motagua River Watershed: waste characterization 2.A. National Secretariat of Science and Technology to connect the national innovation prize with our 2021 Innovation Challenge (UNDP – UNICEF) inviting stakeholders as speakers and panelists on Climate Change Forum.

1.A. UNDP Environment Programme ·         Binational Project for the Management of the Motagua River Basin (MARN-UNDP-GEF) ·         Grant obtained along with the EP and Acc Lab Solutions Mapping on $150,000 AECID – FONTEC. "Empowerment of women in conditions of vulnerability through nature-based enterprises, for the reduction of violence" to communities of Pachalum, Quiché and Nahualá, Sololá.   2.A. Along with Small Grants Programme – GEF, as UNDP Acc Lab, we launched the 2021 Innovation Challenge to accelerate community solutions on waste management and clean energy. With SGP we are addressing the acceleration of the winning solution, Mosan. 2.B. Along with UNICEF, the Acc Lab launched the Innovation Challenge 2021, called “Innovando Juntos por la Niñez y Desarrollo Sostenible”. Besides the logistics, communication, and open call strategy, from the Acc Lab, we provided with top innovators as speakers and mentors (certified on Design Thinking) through the 10-day participatory process. 4.A. Process of hiring a UNV (youngster) from the Ideathon journey to join Solutions Mapping Area.

We work with several organizations in order to get information for mapping and testing local Citizen Science projects.  To be more specific, we tested with AppEAR –a mobile app to identify water bodies and their characteristics- and LabCiudadano –an iniciative to weigh and characterize household waste.

We also work together with and Gato y La Caja, a communication, research and design project, in order to spread dynamic and interesting information about our loop and insights.

In our country, most local Citizen Science projects are linked to public universities. So, for our Citizen Science mapping, we rely on scientists and professionals affiliated with some of the most highly named public universities in our country. This includes University of Buenos Aires, University of San Martin and University of La Plata.

links.target: National Ministry of Science, Technology and Innovation (MINCYT)
description: In our work in Citizen Science, two key governmental partners have been the National Ministry of Science, Technology and Innovation (MINCYT) and the National Ministry of Environment and Sustainable Development (MAyDS). With MINCYT, we team up with members of the Ministry, and together we worked in contacting informants, collecting information, and presenting it to visualize 30+ solutions across the country. With MAyDS, we worked together to scale an air quality citizen science project into a national policy. We also worked with 4 municipalities in Buenos Aires province to implement 2 citizen science experiments, that were designed to test the possible behavioral effects of citizen science projects and in the implications of citizen science for development and public policy, respectively.

Marmara Municipalities Union (MMU) was one of our partners with whom we launched an open call to select a municipality. Here, the role of MMU was sharing its network ties and presence in the region and handling coordination with the municipality.  During the design phase, we worked with Urban Strategy (Kentsel Strateji), a consultancy firm founded by an academic, who facilitated most of the workshops with residents. Their role was to translate the data collected during workshops into a design brief that could be used by the Japanese partner Sotonoba.   Our latest partner is Architecture for All (Herkes Icin Mimarlik, an NGO set up by architects who specialize in participatory design methods, who coordinated the building work in September & October. Their involvement was deemed necessary due to the lack of design and implementation capacity at the municipality.

We worked with masters students from the Catholic University of Asunción on analysis of social capital and the use of information technology among informal recylcers for our learning loop in inclusive recycling.

For our experiment about flexible manufacturing we worked with a national apparell brand (Martel) to train quality monitors and to establish and carry out contracts for the production of school smocks in apparell workshops in the Yaguaron garment cluster. The apparell workshop association of Yaguaron was a key partner for designing and carrying out a census of apparell workshops in the cluster.  For our inclusive recycling learning loop we collaborated withe local coca cola bottler (Paresa) to develop a prototype of household recycling pickup service.

links.target: The Ministry of Labor, Employment and Social Security, Directorate of Social Security
description: The Ministry of Labor, Employment and Social Security, Directorate of Social Security, was a key partner in the development, design and execution of our learning loops on domestic workers and construction work. The National Innovation Strategy, the Ministry of Industry and Commerce (MIC),  and the National Profesional Promotion Service (SNPP) were key partners for the flexible manufacturing learning loop and the SME promotion and formalization portfolio we are developing for 2023. SNPP provided instructors that we trained as quality monitors and time keepers for the manufacturing experiment and the MIC is collaborating with us to carry out surveys of SMEs in the food service, automotive, and tourism and hospitality industries of two districts in order to inform the design SME support services for local "Entreprenuer Support Centers" in these localities.

In the first 100 days of our learning cycle, we worked with Business Mauritius (informally) to gather data on COVID-19's impact on businesses in Mauritius. We are also in the process of striking a collaboration with a private sector entity called 'Made in Moris', which comprises of 130+ businesses using local production means and aiming to completely localise supply chains.

Since October 2021, we have been working with the Ministry of Tourism to develop a roadmap for tourism recovery in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic. This collaboration in ongoing and is formalised by a consultancy activity that UNDP is driving. The Accelerator Lab is assisting in this endeavour.  We are also collaborating with the Mauritius Research and Innovation Council (MRIC) with whom we are signing the formal MoU this month (February 2021).

Since October 2021, we have been working with the Ministry of Tourism to develop a roadmap for tourism recovery in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic. This collaboration in ongoing and is formalised by a consultancy activity that UNDP is driving. The Accelerator Lab is assisting in this endeavour.  We are also collaborating with the Mauritius Research and Innovation Council (MRIC) with whom we are signing the formal MoU this month (February 2021).

Our Lab worked with the Global Centre for Technology, Innovation and Sustainable Development in Singapore to design and develop a data collection platform (Kobo Questionnaire) to collect data on grassroots innovators and innovations in Mauritius, Rodrigues and Seychelles. This data collection platform is in 3 languages: Creole, French and English to help maximise input from the local community.  We also worked with the UNV (Kenya and HQ) to recruit a cohort of 6 UN Community Volunteers across Mauritius, Rodrigues and Seychelles. We managed to recruit these UNVs, who are now working with the Lab until May 2022 (extendable) to help us with data collection efforts to build a Grassroots Innovation Database (noufitir.org).  UNDP is collaborating with the Digital Public Goods Alliance to constitute a repository of technology solutions (mobile apps, software, etc.,) which can freely be used all over the world. The Acc Lab has facilitated a conversation between the Prime Minister's Office of Mauritius and UNDP/DPGA to discuss the possible inclusion of a mobile app called lespwar that tackles gender-based violence in Mauritius.   Finally, at the start of 2021, our Lab collaborated with the International Organisation for Migration (IoM) on this particular question: How the Mauritian diaspora can be roped in the better defining and examining of national issues, and contributing (in an innovative manner) to the development of solutions?  The aim was to build the capacity of the Mauritian Government to strengthen linkages with the Mauritian Diaspora, contributing to an increased diaspora contribution to the social and economic development of Mauritius and promoting an increased Mauritian diaspora engagement.
