The Acc Lab has facilitated a conversation between the Prime Minister's Office of Mauritius and UNDP/DPGA to discuss the possible inclusion of a mobile app called lespwar that tackles gender-based violence in Mauritius.   Finally, at the start of 2021, our Lab collaborated with the International Organisation for Migration (IoM) on this particular question: How the Mauritian diaspora can be roped in the better defining and examining of national issues, and contributing (in an innovative manner) to the development of solutions?  The aim was to build the capacity of the Mauritian Government to strengthen linkages with the Mauritian Diaspora, contributing to an increased diaspora contribution to the social and economic development of Mauritius and promoting an increased Mauritian diaspora engagement.

TakaNiAjira started as a Sustainable Global Goals Initiative aimed at solving waste and employment challenges, set up under Zaidi Recyclers Company in 2018. TakaNiAjira Foundation aims to strengthen financial and technical support to individuals and organizations involved in environmental management, nationally and internationally. TakaNiAjira Foundation was officially registered as non-governmental organization (Foundation) on 11th August 2022.

The Observatory became an important ally within the university, supporting activities related to the collection and analysis of data for the production of reports and also in accompanying the teams in the implementation of their pilots, specifically in the field work.

Tonibung who is a social enterprise that does appropriate technology for rural communities and Moyog Innovation House who trains the entrepreneurs and farmers to use the solar dryer for enterprise and self consumption purposes.

Kota Kita Foundation is the main civil society partner of this project. Since the project's inception they have been closely involved in determining the project's scope, framework, and design. They are also tasked with organizing the field missions, establishing contact with local communities, and participating in the foresight workshops.

The National Research and Innovation Agency (BRIN) have been closely involved from the beginning of the project in determining its scope, framework, and design. They have also participated in workshops, discussions, and the analysis of insights.

The Nusantara Capital City Authority (OIKN) is a cabinet-level agency formed by the Government of Indonesia that works directly under the President. The agency is tasked with managing and governing the city of Nusantara, the future capital located in East Kalimantan. UNDP is currently maintaining active communication with OIKN to update project progress and gain feedback along the way. They have been involved with the planning of the foresight workshop as well as the report-writing process.

Movés is a project that promotes an effective transition towards efficient, inclusive and low-emission mobility in Uruguay. It is financed by the Global Environment Facility, implemented by UNDP Uruguay and executed by Ministry of Industry and Mining, Ministry of Environment and Ministry of Housing and Land Planning. They are experts in sustainable mobility and are very interested in exploring experiences of tactical urbanism. Therefore, we created a partnership to work together implementing this experiment.  

 

Sub-national government of Canelones: the state government supported the project, provided the infrastructure, technical expertise and materials needed to execute the intervention. They also allowed the intervention in a public area and actively participated in the coordination of the whole process. The local government also supported operations through human resources.

 

Municipality of Ciudad de la Costa was also key in the whole process as they participated not only by providing materials location and their opinion, but also inviting neighbors to participate in it.

The Malay local government unit (LGU) has earmarked budget for project initiatives based on initial experiments done in the previous year. Heads LGU offices comprise the Steering Committee of the Multi-Stakeholder Group.

The Compliant Association of Boracay is the private sector representative to the Multi-Stakeholder Group. The private sector is keen on working with government and different stakeholders to ensure the continued recovery and sustainability of Boracay as a tourist destination, including opportunities to explore and raise awareness on sustainable financing.

Malay College is a newly-established local (community) college that currently offers three bachelor’s programs in Tourism, Hospitality, and Entrepreneurship (expected first batch of graduates by 2025) and is in the process of approving additional program offers. The College is open to research placements for the Multi-Stakeholder Group.

The Boracay Women Producer's Cooperative is the civil society representative to the Multi-Stakeholder Group. CSOs, farmer's groups, and cooperatives have been involved in co-creation for the Food Systems Innovations. Their local knowledge helps align the project with experiences on the ground.

The government sector stakeholders provided a strong collaboration in minimizing the indiscriminate waste at Saint Matin's Island. Their technical support in partnership with us accelerated the entire process from team building to awareness raising among the community and the tourist coming to St. Martin's. Bangladesh Tourism Board, a leading govt. sector entity in tourism development extended their hand by distributing waste bins at the beach and other roadside shops, lanes, household areas in Saint Martin's Island. At the same time, it was almost impossible to convince the people for throwing the waste in particular bins without the intervention of local administrative bodies as such the District Administration, Union Council, Executive Committee, and local leaders.

Throughout the process, they were tasked with identifying the geographical scope, conduct the collective mapping activity and upload these information on open-source platforms that are available for UNDP, government partners and the public.

links.target: Institute for Forecasting and Macroeconomic Research
description:
Ministry of economic development and poverty reduction of Uzbekistan - the ministry of economic development and poverty reduction of Uzbekistan is the main coordinating government agency for implementation of the green growth strategies. A representative of the ministry was part of the core team who worked on implementing this exercise.

Center for Economic Research and Reforms under the President’s Administration is one of the leading think-tanks in Uzbekistan with significant influence and impact in development of policy. The director of the Center is at the same time Deputy to the President’s Advisor of economic issues. A representative of the center was part of the core team who worked on implementing this exercise.

Institute for Forecasting and Macroeconomic Research - The Institute is under the Ministry of economic development and poverty reduction and its research/forecast arm. A representative of the institute was part of the core team worked with us on the initiative.

Our collaboration with Berkane Province has been a key

aspect of the Smart City Caravan initiative. We have provided extensive

assistance and shared our expertise in smart city development with the

province’s employees. This partnership has involved offering technical

assistance and guidance on integrating advanced digital technologies and

sustainable urban development practices.

The focus of our engagement has been to empower provincial

employees with the knowledge and skills needed to implement and manage smart

city technologies effectively. Through workshops, training sessions, and

hands-on support, we have worked closely with them to understand and leverage

digital twin technology, IoT, and data-driven decision-making processes.

Our collaboration has not only facilitated the technological 

transformation of Berkane but also ensured that local government staff are

adept at using these technologies for the betterment of their urban

environment. This exchange of expertise and learning has been pivotal in

strengthening the capabilities of Berkane Province in the realm of smart city

development, paving the way for more informed, efficient, and sustainable urban

governance.

links.target: MAJAL Berkane Local Development Company (Gov owned)
description:
Our partnership with MAJAL Berkane Local Development Company has been focused on capacity building in the domain of smart city development. We have been actively involved in equipping MAJAL with the necessary skills and knowledge to effectively implement and manage smart city technologies and strategies. This collaboration has included a series of tailored training sessions, workshops, and advisory services that cover various aspects of smart urban planning, digital twin technology, and sustainable urban management practices.

Our engagement with MAJAL Berkane aims to strengthen their capabilities in driving the smart city initiatives within the region. By sharing our expertise and insights, we are assisting them in becoming a leading force in the transformation of urban spaces into smarter, more sustainable, and efficient environments. This partnership not only enhances MAJAL's internal competencies but also contributes significantly to the broader goal of advancing smart city development in the region.

GIAN (Gujarat Grassroots Innovation Augmentation Network): Nacida en 1997 en India como la primera incubadora de innovaciones de base, fundada en colaboración con el gobierno de Gujarat y apoyada por SRISTI e IIMA además de Honey Bee Network.

GIAN liderará los espacios de capacitación, en colaboración con el AccLab, y brindará herramientas y materiales conceptuales para la implementación del mapeo de soluciones en Colombia. En este momento estamos considerando el desarrollo de un piloto de mapeo de soluciones, para iniciar la práctica dentro de los equipos del PNUD.

links.target: Secretaría de Relaciones Exteriores de México (Foreign Affairs Ministry)
description: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs summons multi-sector stakeholders to inform the position of Mexico for the Intergovernmental Negotiation Committee for the creation of a legally binding instrument for the elimination of plastic waste and UNDP, as leader of the United Nations System workgroup on Green Economy and Climate Change, coordinated the UN participation in the dialogues. More specifically, the Lab’s role was to design and facilitate participatory dialogues with civil society, youth and public in general to capture their perceptions around the elimination of plastic waste.

We worked with Ghana Innovation Hub Network and Widows & Orphans Movement (WOM). We established the partnership with Ghana Innovation Hub Network and signed MOU. We identified and connected with some informal innovators through the Network. WOM is one of the innovators we filmed for the documentary. WOM shared their everyday experiences and their perspectives, expectations about AfCFTA as an entrepreneur.

We worked with Ghana Innovation Hub Network and Widows & Orphans Movement (WOM). We established the partnership with Ghana Innovation Hub Network and signed MOU. We identified and connected with some informal innovators through the Network. WOM is one of the innovators we filmed for the documentary. WOM shared their everyday experiences and their perspectives, expectations about AfCFTA as an entrepreneur.

We interviewed TAMA, a cosmetics company, and the founder of TAMA. We worked with them to understand from the shea butter value chain to the challenges and opportunities of AfCFTA from the perspective of one of successful companies. Not only a successful case, but we also engaged with small, micro informal enterprises to view AfCFTA from different angles.

Ghana Enterprises Agency (GEA) is a government partner that supports MSMEs to grow. We worked with GEA in identifying enterprises both formal and informal for further discussions and sharing the ideas and landscape of the MSMEs’ ecosystem.
GIZ (Not a UN agency, but a development partner) helped us to connect with informal innovators and was instrumental in bridging partnership with Innovation Hub Network.
The teaching hospital is part of the IsDB project to deliver medical consultations to the telemedicine facility and training for staff.

The Office of the Judiciary has responsibilities related to the administrative functions of the judiciary, such as preparing the annual budget, financial management, supply management, personnel planning, building management, academic work, and promoting judicial work. links.target: Federation of chambers of Commerce, Industry and Agriculture
description: Federation of chambers of commerce, Industry and Agriculture was our source of preliminary information on aggregation models adopted by businesses including informal clusters and facilitated  access to business groups through their network of chambers of commerce. The federation is striving to promote and strengthen cluster approach and had previous attempts to organize non-profit clusters across various sectors but few of them were sustained. They appreciated our support in understanding the root causes of success and failure of these clusters and build on the learning to inform the design of new initiatives aiming at leveraging the common interest of businesses and strengthening aggregation models.

Hebron Leather and Shoe Cluster, Cannan Fair Trade (agrobusiness), Bethlehem Fair Trade Artisans (Handicrafts), and Salfit Furniture Cluster.  Explored their business aggregation models to understand keys to success, gaps and challenges hindering these clusters from realizing their potential. We also brought together a multi-disciplinary team including local and international experts in private sector development, branding and marketing to assess the potential of these aggregation models to adopt more robust and institutionalized mechanisms to expand in the local markets and break into international markets.

The interactive platform (www.monshati.ps) provides information to businesses and wide range of services including access to finance apart of their US $300 million Estidama (sustainability) fund of concessional loans and zero interest loans to micro businesses. The platform is also linked to the physical local helpdesks established at the chambers of commerce apart of the MSME National Helpdesk Scheme launched by the Prime Minister's Office with UNDP support apart of the socio-economic response and recovery plans to mitigate the impacts of COVID-19 on Palestinian MSMEs.

The crowdfunding campaign was officially launched on 17 August 2023 in partnership with the Great Ethiopian Run (GER). The GER is a globally renowned road race organiser that comes into this crowdfunding campaign with a strong track-record in outreach around partnering with UNDP and the rest of the UN to promote the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and fundraise for local worthy causes. The Rebuild Her Business campaign will benefit from the “Running for Cause” charity initiative linked with the annual 10k race held in November 2023.

The Ethiopian Diaspora Trust Fund (EDTF) is an organization that creates a powerful connection between those in need in Ethiopia with the diaspora. Over the past 5 year, the fund has mobilized more than 7 million dollars from the Ethiopian diaspora around the world to support projects and dedicate a crisis relief to support the most vulnerable Ethiopians. Seeing the strategic alignment with Rebuild Her Business , EDTF has promoted the campaign with the diaspora community pledged to support 100 women through the Rebuild Her Business campaign with a $50,000 donation. The partnership is not only to support these women but to lay down a foundation for the future work with UNDP in the peace support projects.

UNDP PH's CE portfolio footprint has expanded from the pioneering work in Pasig City to five cities under the ACE Project. This will further expand to up to 60 cities (20 for deep action and 40 for light touch) under the EU-GEPP. With the new programme about to kick off in Q2 2024 with the first batch of 10 cities, ALab PH is currently preparing for the transition particularly by documenting lessons learned and taking stock of opportunities for growth in three cities (Pasig, Quezon City, and Caloocan).

links.target: Department of Science and Technology (DOST) Grassroots Innovation for Inclusive Development (GRIND) Program
description: The GRIND Programme sits in the DOST Davao Regional Office where the agency's forays into grassroots innovations began. DOST-GRIND and ALab Ph has already scheduled a retrospective exercise in January 2024 to take stock of gains to build on and issues to address moving forward in nurturing grassroots innovations in CE and beyond. These issues include financing for grassroots innovators who tend to be informal entrepreneurs, intellectual property protection, scaling national and local government support to such innovators, and the operational capacity of both DOST and UNDP to provide support to innovators (directly or via intermediaries).

The ACE Project was implemented through the generous support of the Japanese government, which has not only provided funding but also facilitated learning exchanges for local government champions to Japan. Japan has also supported ALab PH’s efforts to explore remote sensing-based innovations to strengthen waste management monitoring, and the lab and Japan Unit are in talks on how such efforts can be pursued. The UNDP CE portfolio team will also define how collaboration with the other EU GEPP agencies (GIZ, Expertise France, and IFC) on specific areas of the CE work (may include national policy particularly green public procurement and EPR implementation, support to entrepreneurs and innovators, and financing).

Technical collaboration & data partnership for GeoAI platform: The research paper ‘Slavery from Space’  from the Rights Lab, University of Nottingham showcased a novel approach of using geospatial technologies and artificial intelligence to detect the exact locations of brick kilns using satellite imagery. After the research identified 47,000 precise locations of brick kilns, we connected with the University and now have a technical and data collaboration.  AccLab has repurposed their research for air pollution and extended the research to classify brick kilns based on the environmental (non) compliance using AI algorithms and citizen science. This data is now part of the back-end of our technology platform (app+web-based) which is now being used by state environmental regulators for state wide implementation.

We are partnering with Bihar State Pollution Control Board to roll out the GeoAI platform in their state. This agency is the key environment regulator for monitoring air pollution in the state of Bihar https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/patna/mou-inked-to-check-pollution-through-artificial-intelligence/articleshow/80773918.cms

links.target: Centre for Energy and Environment Nepal (CEEN)
description: We partnered with Centre for Energy and Environment Nepal (CEEN) to prototype the RDF, construct a locally made shredding machine and conduct an emission test along with market feasibility research for the RDF.

We were able to partner with three private sectors. 1. We worked with Bikash Udyami Private Limited to conduct the research, especially to collect data from the field, on exploring the avenues of plastic waste management. 2. We partnered with Green Roads Waste Management Private Limited to explore and test the possibility of plastic mixed bricks. We were able to prototype the bricks, conduct its compressibility test and after the positive results, coordinated with Pokhara Metropolitan City Office to construct a demo-toilet made out of these bricks. 3. In partnership with Avni Ventures, we were able to conduct an assessment on the viability of using non-recyclable plastics in cement factories and its viable market along with the potential cost for Multi-Layered Plastic (MLP) segregation.

links.target: Pacific Islands Association of Non-Governmental Organizations (PIANGO)
description: Piloted a participatory futures methodology with PIANGO – Pacific Islands Association of Non-Governmental Organizations. As part of UNDP’s ongoing support, UNDP facilitated two-part foresight exercise in the PIANGO group retreat in December – one on anticipatory futures to elicit thinking on the future of civil society with focus on consensus building, and other to translate the vision into ideas for PIANGO’s strategy development as well as joint actions with UNDP’s Public Finance Management project over next five years.

With the Ministry of Health in Fiji, a strategic foresight workshop was designed where we facilitated a scenario planning and visioning exercise with all stakeholders working on NCDs in Fiji to build collective vision, support the identification joint action areas, and inform governance structure and processes of the High-Level Steering Committee, which is still in formation. The aim was to improve existing planning and coordination processes.   As next steps, we will continue to support the consultation process with key collaborators and stakeholders and review the governance structure for Wellness/NCD which can be accommodative of multiple scenarios and emerging health trends.   In Vanuatu, the Ministry of Internal Affairs is the largest Ministry with many departments (and more departments added this year) each with their own programs and partners, so a cohesive approach is essential. There are gaps and opportunities with many potential partners emerging but duplication, poor focus, sharing of resources (human and financial) and inter-operational IT, and integrated databases is a challenge. With limited budget and increasing public expectations of service delivery – a more sector wide approach is needed to “future fit” the Ministry to ensure that as a Central Line Ministry it is “fit for purpose” – delivering and creating opportunities for delivery of decentralised services to the provinces where 74.5% of the citizens of Vanuatu reside. UNDP/VEEP is in Q1 2022 supporting the Ministry with a Sector Strategy Workshop with Government ministries, departments, provincial structures, donors, UN and NGO stakeholders to explore the opportunities for strong sector wide anticipatory planning, harmonization, identification of risks and opportunities. Alongside Ministry of Indigenous Affairs, 4 workshops were held in 3 villages in two settings: (a) Votua Village in the Ba Province of Ba, and (b) second bringing together Kava farmers from different parts of the Province of Kadavu. The workshops utilized imaginations as a data point for policy making in the local governance space. The methodology used was inclusive imaginaries, adapted to focus on anticipatory governance. This was part of Deep Listening Exercise of Social Innovation Methodology of ALC.

We are having interviews with members of civil society organizations that are currently approaching AI from different perspectives. Some are working in the field of bid data and computer sciences, such as Dr. Fernando Schapachnik, current director of Sadosky Foundation, and Dr. Daniel Yankelevich, director of the data area of FUNDAR Foundation. We have also been in contact with Dr. Luciana Benotti and Dr. Laura Alemany, members of ViaLibre Foundation, who are concerned with the ethical development of AI. Additionally, we have interviewed Ms. Ivanna Feldfeber, co-founder and executive officer of DataGenero, an organization approaching AI from a gender perspective; Juan Manuel Garcia, Research Coordinator of Derechos Digitales, an organization aimed at advancing human rights within digital contexts. From the interviews, we are drawing insights and indicators of patterns of development of AI.

We are having interviews with members of civil society organizations that are currently approaching AI from different perspectives. Some are working in the field of bid data and computer sciences, such as Dr. Fernando Schapachnik, current director of Sadosky Foundation, and Dr. Daniel Yankelevich, director of the data area of FUNDAR Foundation. We have also been in contact with Dr. Luciana Benotti and Dr. Laura Alemany, members of ViaLibre Foundation, who are concerned with the ethical development of AI. Additionally, we have interviewed Ms. Ivanna Feldfeber, co-founder and executive officer of DataGenero, an organization approaching AI from a gender perspective; Juan Manuel Garcia, Research Coordinator of Derechos Digitales, an organization aimed at advancing human rights within digital contexts. From the interviews, we are drawing insights and indicators of patterns of development of AI.

Our interviews include researchers and scholars working on AI. Some belong to public institutions, such as public universities or the national body for search (CONICET, for its Spanish acronym); other work within private universities. As it happens with civil society organizations, the profile of the academic partners we are working with is diverse. We have maintained conversations with natural language specialists, philosophers, big data and statistic specialists, computer scientists, among others. We have been in touch with Dr. Carolina Aguerre and Maia Levy Daniel, both connected to the Center for Studies in Technology and Society based at the University of San Andrés; also, with Dr. Enzo Tagliazucchi and Dr. Olga Cavalli, both connected to the National University of Buenos Aires. As mentioned before, from the interviews, we are drawing insights and indicators of patterns of development of AI. 

In November of 2023, together with San Andrés University, we organized a free and open seminar on AI and development. We invited experts, practitioners, and policymakers to discuss how AI can have a positive impact on sectors such as health, justice, government and business. Challenges and risks were also discussed.

Together with Citibeats, a social listening company, we conducted a study regarding what people in the country are thinking and saying in social media about AI. Humai (a learning platform) and MultiplAI Health (a startup that uses AI for health diagnoses) are private partners that we invited to take part in the seminar we organized to discuss the impact of AI on development. For the rest of the cycle, we hope to engage in conversations with other private partners, Eryx (software company) and Stämm (biotechnology company), to promote a greater reach of our portfolio of actions regarding AI.

We maintained conversations with the Subsecretary of Public Innovation responsible for some of the preliminary regulations on AI in the country. Beyond this contact, we intend to approach the new national authorities. The country celebrated national elections at the end of 2023 and a new government has been elected. Once it becomes clear what the next administration will dictate regarding AI, we plan to approach the new authorities to share our work, hoping to engage them in our challenge

We were able to submit nominations for five experts from Argentina

Organizations of Persons with Disabilities (OPD's): Maldives Autism Association, Beautiful Eyes Down Syndrome Association, Care Society Maldives, Maldives Deaf Association, Maldives Association of Physical Disables, and Villi Joali.  Inputs from OPD during Collective Intelligence workshop helped us to refine and enhance the initial issue mapping and stakeholder mapping undertaken by the Accelerator Lab. Insights from OPDs were instrumental in filling the gaps in our knowledge. Moreover, OPDs also contributed to creating a solutions brief and in mapping such solution(s) or close solutions that already exists and may have already been tested and tried.   Stakeholder consultations for policy validation. OPDs also actively contributed to the discussion around policy validation. Specifically, in this platform, we concentrated on unpacking practical considerations in implementing the policy.

Civil Service Commission: We worked with the Civil Service Commission (CSC) to support them in the policy process, focusing on creating employment pathways for Persons with Disabilities (PWDs) in Civil Service employment. As part of this process, CSC and Accelerator Lab engaged with different actors including Persons with disabilities, CSO's, government and private sector. We also conducted a Collective Intelligence Design workshop convening multiple stakeholders from different parts of the system. Additionally, during the lab field missions the lab carried out immersion walks, direct conversations PWD's and civil service offices based in the islands (local council secretariats, health facilities and schools) to understand key factors for consideration to ensure successful policy implementation on the ground.

Resident Coordinator's office: in the Collective Intelligence workshop and contributed towards understanding the ongoing initiatives, identifying avenues for resources, and bringing in the global and the local context. There is potential to expand the conversation in the next stages and identify further avenues for collaboration.

links.target: Design Ethnography Lab, Bandung Institute of Technology (DE Lab ITB)
description:
DE ITB primarily supports in designing Solutions Mapping Canvas. The solutions mapping canvas consists of a practical guide, field notes and canvas that facilitates anyone to immerse themselves in community dynamics, identify and systematically map grassroots solutions and their complexities. The canvas is expected to provide a deep understanding of the aspirations, solutions, needs, challenges, and opportunities that exist in the community. The canvas is made as simple as possible so that it can be understood and applied by various groups.

To expand the reach of using canvas in an inclusive manner, there are several strategic steps that we want to take: 

a. Design Inclusive Solutions Mapping Cards. The Solutions Mapping canvas will be redesigned and transformed into inclusive cards with contextualized, common glossaries and/or tailored to special needs. On-site consultation with communities is required to bring our Solutions Mapping cards to life efficiently and receive context-based feedback from communities.

Solutions Mapping Platform (Website). The refined tools, including the curated grassroots and social innovations, will be published on the Solutions Mapping website platform so that they can be accessed by the wider community.

Solutions Mapping Dissemination Event. Our learnings will be disseminated publicly to introduce our Solutions Mapping tools and highlight the importance of mundane and daily solutions to communities. The dissemination event aims to provide an exciting and stimulating setting for an enjoyable and worthwhile learning process about Solutions Mapping and Immersion methods.

The UNDP- Accelerator Lab in Iraq worked with Baghdad Business Schools, She Codes too, and Meta for implementing Women Bootcamp for programming initiative. This initiative aims to support women in joining the digitalization movement in Iraq and open spaces for employment opportunities in this space. The hiring Baghdad Business School aligned efforts with an international company, is called Meta,  as well as cooperate with a coding institute, is called She Codes Too,  to jointly localize a well-recognized coding course and produce free-of-charge women's boot camp for six months, incorporating both offline and online learning modality, that aim to improve programming skills necessary for women to excel in the digital space.

This Network was one of the key partners for the initiative, they bring together the civil society organizations that participate in the process at the local level. They were the counterpart organization in the responsible party agreement that included the objectives and activities for implementing the native forest restoration actions.

links.target: Ministry of Livestock, Agriculture, and Fisheries
description: National Government: Ministry of Environment & Ministry of Livestock, Agriculture, and Fisheries. The defense of the native forest is aligned with the public policies and strategies of the State, carried out by the three ministries, among which the National Environmental Plan, the National Biodiversity Strategy, the National Climate Change Policy, the National Strategy for Native Forest and the Ecosystem Restoration Plan. We involved them in the crowdfunding and crowdsourcing process as institutional allies. The General Forestry Directorate of the Ministry of Livestock, Agriculture, and Fisheries and the Biodiversity and Ecosystemic Services Directorate of the Ministry of Environment provided technical assistance on the native forest. They had expert knowledge on which are the native species to plant in each place. The CO has worked with the ministries previously, as they are part of the Plantaton initiative. Sub-national government: the state government supported the project, provided the machinery needed, and allowed the intervention in a public area. The local government also supported operations and through human resources.

We generated an alliance with the International Organization for Migration (IOM). They were interested in mapping the Uruguayan diaspora, and they saw the crowdfunding campaign as an opportunity to identify Uruguayans who live abroad that want to contribute with an environmental cause in Uruguay. They helped communicating in their social media and contacts all the campaign.

The Ministry of Foreign Relations expressed interest in undertanding the effects of migration flows for local communities and the identification of opportunities to increase the resilience of local communities. The ministry assigned a focal point to facilitate interinstitutional coordination, especially with the Ministry of Security for activities on the ground; as well as other relevant government actors such as local institutions, Comarca Emberá Wounaan governors and others.

IOM and the Human Mobility Group (GMH) facilitated the coordination of interviews and focus groups with different UN Agencies and international cooperation organizations at the national and local level, which as key to access different sources of data and perspectives, as well as an integrated understanding of local actions on the ground.

The Emberá - Wounaan Congress is the traditional traditional government structure of the Comarca Emberá Wounaan. They provided the consent to conduct this R&D process, as well as the delegation of a focal point, the president of the congress of Nokoras (local authorities) to participate throughout the process.

GeoIndígena is an indigenous NGO that focuses on the use of GIS technologies to support indigenous territories to strengthen their capabilities for the protection and vigilance of forests, as well as territorial planning and local governance activities in indigenous territories. Their support was key for the free, prior and informed consent, as well as the social cartography and deep listening process.

Almanaque Azul, in partnership with GeoIndigena, were the responsible parties of UNDP on the ground to lead the development of this R&D process. They are an NGO that focuses on education and research to protect the natural and cultural biodiversity of Panama.

links.target: Department of Environment, Government of Bangladesh
description: Realizing the importance of sea turtle in marine biodiversity preservation, UNDP Bangladesh didn't make any delay to conserve and ensure the safe hatching of the vulnerable turtle at Saint Martin's Island. As the Department of Environment (DoE) has already been working on the protection on ocean biodiversity and environmental conservation, they were preserving the turtle's egg on trial basis. In this they allocated land for making hatchery near the office of DoE at Saint Martin's. With DoE's support, UNDP has provided technical assistance in collecting the turtle eggs by employing workers at Saint Martin's. Also, the team was observing the number of turtles coming to lay eggs on the beach, intervals and frequency of their coming, number of eggs they lay, proportion of the baby turtles hatched in comparison to the number of eggs kept for hatching.

Collaborative actions were developed with non-traditional partners, such as El Gato y La Caja (a participatory group and a research, communication and design platform reaching hundreds of thousands of Spanish-speaking people, https://elgatoylacaja.com/). We also co-organized with FARN a workshop to bring citizen science practices closer to the design of environmental public policies to clean up the Matanza Riachuelo Basin.

The citizen science solutions mapping was co-created with the Argentine Ministry of Science, Technology, and Innovation (MINCYT).  Along the way, we built and iterated our mapping cards where we included descriptions of the initiatives, the purpose of which is to systematize the information collected and enable comparisons. All the information was validated by the leaders of each of the initiatives.. Now, the solutions mapping is currently growing collaboratively. In October 2022, MINCYT created a nationwide program of federal promotion of local citizen science. This program, in 2023, will finance citizen science projects; expand mapping and set up permanent initiatives monitoring, identifying opportunities, challenges and lessons learned at different stages, according to the diversity of participants and methodologies used; promote civil society participation in these types of initiatives; foster citizen science training, participatory research methodologies and other related areas of expertise; and encourage studies and research related to citizen science in Argentina to feed public policies in various areas of intervention. In 2022, we continued our partnership with the National Ministry of Science, Technology, and Innovation and the cities of Buenos Aires, Quilmes, San Antonio de Areco, Balcarce and Mercedes, in the province of Buenos Aires, Argentina.

links.target: Department of the Interior and Local Government (DILG)
description: DILG supervises local governments and implements programmes to strengthen their capacity. It will serve as the main partner for the envisaged AAA local government programme.

DBM oversees public expenditures and, related to LGUs, manages the release of local allocations from the national budget and works with DILG and other key agencies to manage the devolution process. DBM is also the ministerial point of contact for the Open Government Partnership (OGP).

ZEP2030 PH is a coalition of more than 140 non-government entities—including the biggest civil society federations in the Philippines—aimed at converging their efforts to lift millions from poverty. ALab PH has been collaborating with ZEP2030 PH as a coalition and with its individual members to accelerate the nurturing of local convergences or multi-stakeholder networks.

ALab PH has collaborated with 15 local convergences or multi-stakeholder networks to introduce AAA governance-inspired methodologies for participatory planning for post-COVID recovery in 2022. ALab PH is currently checking in on these local convergences to gather insight for the envisaged AAA local government support programme.

As UNDP PH seeks to strengthen its engagement in open governance as part of the AAA local governance programme, it has increased its collaboration in recent years with the OGP Support Unit—the global and regional body that is helping to steer the OGP—to harmonize and converge their support to DBM, DILG, and civil society organizations.

description: We worked with Science and Technology Park in Erdenet. But we worked with an NGO on the other waste experiment, which is not completed. These 2 experiments and partners coordinated and shared some insights.

links.target: Ministry of Education of the Government of the City of Buenos Aires
description:
The citizen science solutions mapping was co-created with the Argentine Ministry of Science, Technology, and Innovation (MINCYT). Along the way, we built and iterated our mapping cards where we included descriptions of the initiatives, the purpose of which is to systematize the information collected and enable comparisons. All the information was validated by the leaders of each of the initiatives. On October 2022, the MINCYT created a National Citizen Science Program.  

Among other activities carried out throughout 2023, the AccLab is part of the Advisory Committee for the National Citizen Science Program and co-coordinated the evaluation of grants for projects in that program. 

We partnered with the Ministry of Education of the Government of the City of Buenos Aires to promote the establishment of the 'Citizen Science in Schools Program' along with the Center for Research on the Sea and the Atmosphere (CIMA-CONICET-UBA), Institute of Physical Chemistry of Materials, Environment, and Energy (INQUIMAE-CONICET-UBA), and the Department of Physics-Exact Sciences at the University of Buenos Aires. This program deploys three citizen science projects in 57 schools, involving more than 100 teachers and 1,000 students to measure the city's air quality using passive tubes installed in strategically located schools; monitor, forecast, and generate weather alerts related to hydro-meteorological events; and map the Earth's magnetic field using a mobile application. 

The experiments were conducted in and with the support of the municipal governments of Quilmes, San Antonio de Areco, Mercedes and Balcarce. Lastly, we will present the report with the results of the experiment along with the Argentine Network of Municipalities against Climate Change which gathers 286 local governments, highlighting the innovative quality of this approach and how useful cities found it
We worked with the university of Hargeisa's faculty and dean in the data gathering stage of the challenge.

We collaborated with the ministry of Youth in Hargeisa to conduct a foresight workshop, in addition to collaborating and helping them host an event with the theme of improving the educational system and solutions for the problem.

We worked and are still working with UNFPA in a partnership to improve and utilize several youth centres in different cities. In terms of this challenge we used these centres as entry points to communities and youth in particular for experimenting with TVET and STEAM training.

The experiments are ongoing and because we partnered with GEF SGP, all of the recipients of funds are NGOs. They are all implementing the solutions and reporting on their impact at a community and national level. 
1. Cashew Gardens Community Council (CGCC): This project will develop an edible spoon as well as a green market, at which the community will sell their spoon and garden produce
2. The Department of Electrical & Computer Engineering, UWI: This project will use waste plastic filament to develop a local stem kit for youths
3. National Centre for Persons with Disabilities: This project will use waste plastic to produce tools for PWDs, will set up a community garden for PWDs and will establish an online marketplace for products made by PWDs
4. CEDAW Committee of Trinidad and Tobago: This will install benches with gender messaging in public spaces
5. Rotary Club of Port of Spain West (RCPOSW): This project will prototype equipment for collecting plastics in rivers
6. Alliance of Rural Communities of Trinidad and Tobago:	This project will expand the production of natural, sustainable packaging as alternatives to plastic packaging
SHIFT! Caribbean	Mentorship and capacity support to ensure successfully completion of the 6 other projects.

FOKKALIS is one of the winning grassroot communities from the Urban Innovation Challenge - their role throughout the piloting phase is to design an ecosystem for food loss and waste management in traditional markets, in which they explored the opportunity of digital foodbanks and partnerships with faith-based organizations, food vendors, and government stakeholders.

 

 

Sayur Sleman is one of the winning grassroot communities from the Urban Innovation Challenge - their role throughout the piloting phase is to enhanced their social enterprise by developing elements of digitalization (such as websites) and conduct necessary research to support their market strategy. They are connecting vegetable and fruit vendors in traditional markets with new technology-led market in urban areas to alleviate economic burden due to COVID-19.

CEGAS Studio is one of the winning grassroot communities from the Urban Innovation Challenge - their role throughout the piloting phase is to develop a web-based disaster portal and prototype its functions, while initiating partnerships with relevant government partners, volunteers, banks and private sector partners to ensure its sustainability.

Ecoxyztem is a Venture Builder that serves as a co-partner throughout the Innovation Challenge organization as well as piloting of winners. Their main role throughout the prototyping phase is to conduct frequent monitoring and evaluation as well as provide required capacity building for grassroot communities.

links.target: The Plurinational Authority of the Mother Earth (APMT)
description: The APMT needs to develop an adequate methodology to build indigenous life plans linked to municipal plans. Currently, the methodology is being finalized by our team and will soon be delivered to the APMT.

Kaami is an indigenous territory comprised of 19 indigenous communities in the Chaco region of Bolivia that sought to develop its life plan. Unfortunately, our initial partner, CIRABO, couldn't be a part of this journey due to some misunderstandings that prevented their participation until September in this year.

Camiri is the municipality to which Kaami belongs, with the Autonomous Municipal Government of Camiri (AMGC) serving as the local governing body. The Municipal Territorial Development Plan (PTDI), functioning as the municipal tool for planning. It must incorporate the essential insights from the indigenous life plan to secure financing for this plan implementation.

Natura is an NGO operating in the Chaco region of Bolivia. Its technicians played a crucial role in facilitating workshops with indigenous authorities to formulate their life plan. Their specific role centered on presenting evidence derived from scientific information and field experience, thereby fostering an informed deliberation process

links.target: Ribeira de São Filipe Producers' Association
description:
The collaboration with the University of Cabo Verde demonstrates a strong commitment to research and academic collaboration. The University's expertise in agriculture and technology, led by Sonia Semedo (Principal Investigator in the Artificial Intelligence for Agriculture and Food Systems programme), enhances the project's objectives, and facilitates the transfer of knowledge to the local community.

Sonia Semedo, a distinguished scientist, and researcher is well placed to lead this collaboration, which is further supported by the Arise-PP (African Research for Scientific Excellence) grant. The award of an Arise-PP (African Research for Scientific Excellence) grant underlines the project's commitment to advancing knowledge and promoting excellence.

In this partnership, Accelerator Lab has offered to fund the pilot project with a woman who owns agricultural land in Ribeira de São Filipe, with a focus on women's empowerment, and to help train researchers and farmers in drone management. The university, in turn, is responsible for the research that will lead to the creation of the system to be used in the pilot.

By fostering closer links with the university, the Accelerator Lab also gains access to expertise, research capabilities and resources that can further enhance the effectiveness and impact of its initiatives in addressing the challenges facing Cabo Verde's agricultural sector.

Kenya Community Support Centre (KECOSCE) and Amani FM (A community radio station): Peace champions are now able to connect directly with the radio station to share what is happening in real time through an alert number which is toll-free. KECOSCE and Amani FM accompanied us to the co-design sessions and shared available opportunities with the youth. The co-design sessions with the community groups enabled us to create, deploy or tap into a citizen sensor network to provide real time situational assessment/feedback through WhatsApp which is essential to managing conflict and can be used to help identify potential solutions to be explored, tested and monitored.

links.target: Proyecto Binacional Acción Climática Río Uruguay (Río Uruguay Binational Project on Climate Action)
description: This binational project includes a 4-year action plan. “It intends to develop tools and exchange experiences of planning and management in both countries (Argentina & Uruguay) to contribute to vulnerability reduction and integral risk management, by adopting a climate change adaptation approach and a gender, generation, and human rights-based perspective.” This is how we will approach local communities, and it will also contribute to scaling up actions or plans that arise from these actions. The Binational Project got involved in the first workshop on native flora.

They collaborate with field trips. Thanks to their intervention, we were able to get in touch with new young climate activists. Moreover, in light of the relationship built in this learning cycle, we introduced them to the project leaders of the Renewable Energy Solutions Mapping, and they have already established partnerships with other environmental organizations who were unfamiliar with each other’s work. EcoHouse and the Lab are also considering the possibility of replicating the citizen science experience in the schools of another city.

We partnered with three NGOs for the three different components of the program: Alma Civica implemented the training course with municipal officials, Cultura y Participacion implemented a citizens’ laboratories in two municipalities with public, private, and civil society participation, and Girls Code implemented the civic technology bootcamp and hackathon.

We partnered with three NGOs for the three different components of the program: Alma Civica implemented the training course with municipal officials, Cultura y Participacion implemented a citizens’ laboratories in two municipalities with public, private, and civil society participation, and Girls Code implemented the civic technology bootcamp and hackathon.

Members of the National University of Itapúa and the Autonomous University of Encarnacion participated in the citizens laboratory in Encarnacion. The Autonomous University of Encarnacion was a host and partner for the civic technology bootcamp and hackathon. We also made an alliance with the National University of Itapúa to carry out a university extension project that promotes the participation of students of Computer Science in the bootcamp and hackathon.

Oñoiru, a cooperative organization of yerba mate producers, was the main partner for one of the citizen’s laboratories. They hosted a cocreation session which resulted in an initiative to improve the marketing and promotion of fairtrade yerba mate.

Employees from 12 municipalities in the Department of Itapúa participated in the training course, and the municipality of Encarnacion was the main ally for one of the citizens laboratories, which focused on the problems of unemployment t and poor access to transport of youth in communities displaced by largescale infrastructure projects linked to the flooding of the reservoir of the hydroelectric dam near the city. The laboratory designed a community fair as an intervention aimed at recovering historic memory of the displaced communities as a first step to recovering from the experience of physical and social displacement.

description: Neighborhood Council of Colonia Jardines de la Asunción – Arco 5-6, in zone 5, Guatemala City, and 30 families from the neighborhood.   Neighborhood Council of Colonia Vivibien, in zone 5, Guatemala City, and 40 families from the neighborhood.   Neighborhood Council of Colonia 20 de Octubre, in zone 5, Guatemala City, and 30 families from the neighborhood.    Even though families participated, the most enthusiastic and keen to participate in every stage and detail of the process were women, and most of them were adults in their 50’s or 60’s.  It has been rewarding to learn how neighbors, mostly adults, consider this experience as the beginning of a transformation from their communities, hoping that more neighbors join in. They have shared the initiative with other relatives, friends, other neighbors and even with their workplaces too.

description: Neighborhood Council of Colonia Jardines de la Asunción – Arco 5-6, in zone 5, Guatemala City, and 30 families from the neighborhood.   Neighborhood Council of Colonia Vivibien, in zone 5, Guatemala City, and 40 families from the neighborhood.   Neighborhood Council of Colonia 20 de Octubre, in zone 5, Guatemala City, and 30 families from the neighborhood.    Even though families participated, the most enthusiastic and keen to participate in every stage and detail of the process were women, and most of them were adults in their 50’s or 60’s.  It has been rewarding to learn how neighbors, mostly adults, consider this experience as the beginning of a transformation from their communities, hoping that more neighbors join in. They have shared the initiative with other relatives, friends, other neighbors and even with their workplaces too.

The Lab joined hands with the Volunteers Association for Bangladesh (VAB) – a grassroots organization dedicated to rural education since 2000 - to pilot an innovative e-Learning project. It assisted rural and disadvantaged high school students from 9 schools across five districts - the majority being girls - on their preparation for the 2021 national secondary school certificate (SSC) examination through e-learning via tablets and digital contents.

To better understand the potential and challenges of design, piloting, and subsequently scaling up an online micro-credential scholarship program, the Lab consulted with key stakeholders, especially progressive educational institutions, and potential youth participants of the YEAPI-B program to receive valuable feedback in shaping the program. The lab held consultation workshops with representatives from East West University (EWU), American International University-Bangladesh (AIUB), University of Asia Pacific (UAP), BRAC University, Hajee Mohammad Danesh Science & Technology University (HSTU), and Daffodil International University (DIU).

The lab created partnerships with Women in Digital, UNLEASH Innovation Lab, Reaktor, University of Helsinki, and UltraHack for the UNDP Women’s Digital Innovation Hackathon. Women in Digital was responsible for marketing, promotion, and coordination of the hackathon. UNLEASH Innovation Lab provided resources on the innovation process and it served as the official format of the Hackathon. In addition, 10 UNLEASH Alumni connected virtually during the Hackathon period from Bangladesh, India, Denmark, Japan, USA, Germany, and Hong Kong over the hackathon days and served as facilitators to guide the teams through the innovation process and the hackathon activities. UltraHack provided the technical infrastructure for conducting the hackathon virtually.  Finally, Reaktor & University of Helsinki conducted workshops on their online ‘Elements of Artificial Intelligence’ course and made the course available at free-of-cost to 100 hackathon participants.

In this collaboration, the UNDP Accelerator Lab and Fulbright University Vietnam are working together to explore the future of work in Vietnam, particularly from the perspective of the youth and in the context of the digital revolution, technological progress, and Industry 4.0. The research aims to identify emerging trends, potential skill gaps, and ways to adapt education and vocational training systems to equip youth with relevant skills for the future of work. Fulbright University, through their network of students and employers and bringing together these groups for the workshops. We are co-designing the foresight workshops with Fulbright, also drawing from their strength in future studies.

Mobile Network Operators: 
MTN Sudan, Zain Sudan and Sudani- we signed NDAs with them to obtain the geolocations of the connectivity tower and consolidated our engagement with them to work with UNDP to prototype solar-powered connectivity.
Whilst two of the MNOs declined to participate in the pilot given the cost-benefit implications on their companies. Sudani was the only one to take this risk with us for which at their own cost deployed a Cell on Wheel to one of the two camps in the East as part of the Ethiopian refugee response for which the other camp is our pilot site.

Energy Providers: 
Empower ESCO (energy service company) we worked with them to co-design the prototype based on the energy specifications of the connectivity towers- BTS, COWs and Wifi Mesh Networks.

GSMA:
The GSMA Association is an industry organisation that represents the interests of the mobile network operators worldwide. We are working with them to scale out the CoNUA assessment and digital literacy training in UNDP GCF project areas in 9 states.

links.target: High School of Civil Engineering and Geodesy
description: Inspired by a similar experience from AccLab Ukraine, and to support the initial mapping efforts necessary to develop the application's logic further, the testing mapathon was conducted in April with the High School of Civil Engineering and Geodesy students in Sarajevo. The students successfully mapped over 150 obstacles in the center of Sarajevo through the testing application in one hour on the field. Their impression was that there were obstacles on each meter of the public space (streets, roads, public buildings, etc.) and that “everything needed to be rebuilt to be accessible to everyone”.

links.target: Da Nang Department of Natural Resources and Environment (DONRE)
description:
With Government Agencies and Public Sector Partners: AccLab partnered with national and local government entities such as the National Innovation Center (NIC), NATEC, DISED, DONRE, and provincial governments. These collaborations focused on co-designing and piloting innovative approaches for policy development, circular economy, and public sector transformation.

With Academic Institutions: AccLab collaborated with universities (FTU, NEU, Fulbright) to enhance training practices, integrate innovation methodologies into curricula, and support research initiatives that address real-world challenges.

With Private Sector Partners: Through joint projects with DNES, Minh Hong BioTech, FUWA, MGreen, and Selex Motors, AccLab provided technical support, training, and capacity building to help businesses adopt circular economy models, experiment with new business practices, and scale sustainable solutions.

links.target: Chamber of Commerce of Cabo Verde (CCB and CCISS)
description: Association of Young Entrepreneurs of Cabo Verde (AJEC) – Partner for operating NEGOCIA Business and Launch the LAVANTA Fund. This association was key partner in de development of NEGOCIA platform and the deployment of LAVANTA Call for Projects phase. They promoted the engagement of their associate members (young entrepreneurs from all islands of Cabo Verde) in the initiative, helped promote it and receive applications via NEGOCIA Platform.   Chamber of Commerce of Cabo Verde (CCB and CCISS) – Partners of NEGOCIA Business Platform. Together with AJEC, they are the beneficiaries of the NEGOCIA Business Platform and development partners. A MoU was signed between them delegating in AJEC the operational management of the platform.   Financial Ecosystem – Composed by banks and other financial institutions (Partial Guarantee, Venture Capital, etc.), this ecosystem was organized by the government to increase access to finance in Cabo Verde. In this process, with the help of PROEMPRESA, this ecosystem was engaged with INFF and SPU (see below) to create an innovative financial instrument, LAVANTA Fund, to promote credit for institutional change for private entrepreneurship and bottom-up innovation.

Ministry of Maritime Economy – Blue economy sectorial partner. The National Movement of Recyclers has been key in guiding our learning process. They are part of our ‘coordination team’ that meets periodically to discuss on progress and learnings from this process. We have collaborated in the application of the quartering methodology for waste characterization and the use of the survey instrument elaborated by them and Farnum & Kelly (2018) in Tonosí. There may be an academic publication generated by the University of Panama.

The University of Buenos Aires: Developed and applied the citizen science method Observe:Waste in Argentina. Upon its adaptation and application in Panama, the developers of the methodology facilitated further guidance of the methodology and its dissemination.    Florida State University Supported the design of the Theory of Change and concept note of the citizen science (marine debris and microplastics) methodology.  The Technological University of Panama  The Center of Hydraulic and Hydromechanics designed the field method used for citizen science (marine debris and microplastics), trained the citizen scientists in the fields of plastics, data collection, data analysis, and legal and regulatory frameworks for plastic. This partner is currently also leading the in-depth analysis of microplastics and is supporting the scaling of the method to Guatemala and El Salvador.  We partnered with the Regional Center of the Technological University of Panama in Azuero to explore alternative solutions to SWM in the southern region of Azuero through the Innovation Fair titled “Reduce, Reuse, Recycle and Be an Entrepreneur”. Given that most eyes look at Panama City when searching for innovation and entrepreneurship, this became an opportunity to explore and showcase innovative solutions emerging from university students of Azuero. In total, there were 24 proposals and the top 3 selected were (i) artificial reefs; (ii) app to find recycling companies in Azuero and (iii) yucca ‘plastic’ in replacement to polystyrene.  University of Panama Raúl Kelly, scholar from the University of Panamá has continously supported our learning process participating actively in the ‘coordination team’ meetings. We have collaborated in the validation and application of the quartering methodology for waste characterization and the use of the survey instrument elaborated by him in Tonosí (Farnum & Kelly, 2018) together with the National Movement of Recyclers.

Coca-Cola: ideation of reverse logistics pilot in Tonosí   After noticing Coca Cola’s presence in Tonosi as a steady distributor, while considering that most residents and businesses are not recycling plastic, the Lab pitched a reverse logistics proposal inspired by Coca Cola’s vision of working towards a ‘World Without Waste’ – aiming to collect and recycle a bottle for everyone sold by 2030.  The proposal, currently under evaluation, encompasses four key elements:  Phase 1: educate participants on waste separation and collect data on the amount of material collected  Phase 2: with the municipality to compact the collected material in the center of Tonosi  Phase 3: evaluate the financial sustainability of the pilot through a relationship with a local recycling company, Recimetal  Phase 4: evaluate the effectiveness of the model and explore options to incorporate the collection process into Coca Cola’s logistics chain.    Recimetal: partner for reverse logistics pilot  Recimetal is one of Panama’s largest recycling companies that has advised the Lab regarding the logistics of recyclable materials in Panama as well as committing to training in plastic compacting as well as retrieval and payment of materials.

links.target: Directorate for Coasts and Seas (DICOMAR), Ministry of Environment (MiAmbiente)
description: Ministry of Environment  The Ministry of Environment (MiAmbiente) is a key partner of the umbrella project under which the learning cycle took place. It’s Directorate for Coasts and Seas (DICOMAR) guided the initial design of the citizen science (marine debris and microplastics) and is currently implementing the use of the mobile app used for data collected in all institutional, ministry-led beach cleanups. MiAmbiente also a participant of the collective intelligence workshop and guided the initial visits to the landfills.    Municipality Tonosí  The municipality of Tonosí has been our strongest institutional partner as it has openly supported the generation of spaces to explore and generate learnings and solutions for SWM in its communities. From the municipal council sessions to present ideas and conduct (and participate of) a collective intelligence workshop, to the support in organizing and following up with citizen science initiative by the municipality and its vice-mayor, it has been a fantastic collaboration.      ANCON (National Association for the Conservation of Nature)  The Lab was invited to assist ANCON in their evaluation of the national recycling project, (Recicla por Tu Futuro), which they manage as one of the key implementors.  The Lab conducted several months of working sessions including a SWOT analysis, leading to a revised improvement plan to be presented to all implementing partners and donors.

The Ministry of Finance acted as a digital transformation champion and facilitated inter-agency collaboration. They are legally responsible for the Digital Strategy of the State of Queretaro. They oversee the design and roll out of digital solutions in all the ministries and government entities of the state. They are our key liason in the government and help us reach out to local actors, access resources to implement our learning cycle (e.g. venues, data, events) and connect our pilot to the state’s strategy to ensure its adoption.

links.target: Centro de Investigación y Docencia Económicas (CIDE))
description: CIDE (Centro de Investigación y Docencia Económicas) served as our strategic knowledge partner throughout the project. Their team provided expertise in organizational change management, public sector innovation, and the ethical integration of artificial intelligence. CIDE led the development of the change management and recommendations guide, facilitated participatory workshops with stakeholders, and contributed to the design and evaluation of the pilot solution. Their involvement ensured that the project was grounded in rigorous academic analysis and best practices for sustainable digital transformation in the public sector.

The partnership between UNDP Thailand and the Thailand Association of the Blind (TAB) focuses on enhancing digital skills training for youth with visual impairments. This collaboration aims to address the challenge of limited employment opportunities for persons with disabilities in Thailand, particularly those with visual impairments.

Key aspects of this partnership include:

Curriculum Development: TAB's expertise in understanding the needs and challenges faced by visually impaired individuals is instrumental in developing an inclusive and accessible training curriculum. Their insights ensure that the training is tailored to effectively impart digital skills to the participants.

Advocacy and Awareness: The partnership also involves efforts to raise awareness about the importance of digital literacy for visually impaired individuals. This includes advocating for more inclusive practices in the workplace and broader society.

Resource Sharing and Expertise: The collaboration likely involves sharing resources and expertise between UNDP Thailand and TAB. This could include sharing training materials, methodologies, and technical expertise.

Feedback and Improvement: TAB's involvement ensures continuous feedback from the visually impaired community, which is crucial for refining and improving the training program.

Farmore: describes itself as an innovator in the Nigerian food system space. The Lab and BAI Hub, engaged Farmore to gain insights from their partnerships with rural small holder farming communities, on how these relationships had works, how knowledge transfers and risks were managed, where traditional techniques could be effectively deployed, the importance of trust in these relationships etc.                                           


Intrio Synergy Ltd.; is another company we engaged during the exploration phase. They engage in R&D and contract farming with small holder rural farming communities in Benue. We learnt from their experiences in knowledge exchanges and business relationship management with these communities. 


Tembekasua - we engaged Tembekasua on the opportunities in leveraging decentralised markets for rural small holder farmers. Access to markets is a critical challenge for many of these farmers. We want to test the efficiency of virtual market places in connecting these farmers to regional and international markets. 


Benue Young Farmers Network & Various Local equipment fabricators: Members of these networks shared intelligence on how their value chains engaged small holder farmers, operational challenges they faced and their innovations.

Benue State SDGs Office: This office supported the Lab's engagement of farmers in all the rural communities we visited, facilitating meetings with different networks, internally displaced persons, translation services and face time with public officials. 


Ministry of Agriculture: The Director shared their own insights on the challenges faced by small holder farmers, strategies that could quickly improve their situations and contacts with various farming networks the Lab could collaborate with. This Ministry will be crucial to effecting policy changes. 

Benue Agriculture and Rural Development Agency: We worked with this agency to understand how the State manages extension services in communities. Scale-up of successful experiments will require their support. 



Benue State Emergency Management Agency (SEMA): We engaged SEMA during exploration to get their insights on displacement trends in Benue. We discovered that SEMA coordinates climatic data from other agencies, and are now collaborating to use this data and their early warning emergency management platform in an experiment. Although this data is not being used to support agricultural practice, we believe it could be greatly impact livelihoods at community level. 


Nigeria Meteorological Agency (NIMET) & Nigeria Hydrological Services Agency (NIHSA): These Federal Agencies generate data on climatic conditions, which are then shared with State Agencies. We engaged them in exploration to understand the range of their operations, if and how these could be tailored to be useful to the small holder farmers.

We collaborated on co-designing the focus groups with the public policy research organization Analytica MK. Analytica MK is well know organization in the country that focuses on the topic of informality and in the previous year has published a report on informal workers that we wanted to build upon. Partnering with them gave us the opportunity to tap into their ecosystem and learning generated over the past years.  Based on the findings from the focus groups we prepared a report on Informal worker’s perceptions and experiences from the informal economy that was shared in the country office.   Some of the key findings of the report are the advantages and disadvantages of the functioning within the informal sector and micronarratives around them;  Furthermore, we are in close cooperation with the Impact Foundation, who are implementing the project RECONOMY that works on improving informed self-employment opportunities through freelancing on digital platforms, including mentoring by already experienced freelancers. We are comparing notes on regular basis as some of our efforts are complimentary to each other.

We cooperated with a Professor from the State Faculty for economics whose scientific research field of interest is public finances, macroeconomic policies, and theory in the co-creation of the reports on Informal worker’s perceptions, where his insights in the tax policies were more than useful in preparing the policy recommendations;

links.target: local government of Guatemala in zone 5
description:
We worked with the local government of Guatemala in zone 5. We conducted workshops to device a transition plan to implement waste-management policies. This effort also involved the Ministry of Environment, and we conducted similar activities with the local government of Estanzuela in the department of Zacapa. 
 
In addition, we started solid waste characterization with municipalities of Estanzuela, Zacapa; and Pachalum, Quiché, both as prioritized municipal territories in the Motagua River Watershed. 
 
We also worked with the Ministry of Environment to assess capacity regarding the use of satellite images, and data management linked to waste. Particularly, the team in charge of the National Information System for Climate Change.

links.target: Camara Municipal de Ribeira Grande de Santiago
description:
The Camara Municipal de Ribeira Grande de Santiago serves as the local governing body for Ribeira Grande de Santiago, a large municipality located on Santiago Island.

Our project was based in Cidade Velha, the capital of the municipality, which is considered one of the most promising tourism destinations on Santiago Island.

The municipality secured funds for this project through a Letter of Agreement (LOA) process, and our lab provided support during the implementation phase.

The funds received were allocated for the following purposes:

Training program, including the contracting of a firm to provide trainings in English, French, and Digital Marketing.

Acquisition of physical bus stops and a tourism kiosk, redesign of public transportation, and development of a website.

As mentioned, this project aimed to empower the community and improve the municipality's tourism information and transportation services.

The Samoa National Youth Council is the recognized youth platform in Samoa both by the Government and other NGOs. In addition, the structure of their membership which are Village Youth Representatives is what was needed for the AccLab to navigate the village locations chosen for the first mapping test.

The other is the Innovators, who are registered as private entities for purposes of commercializing their innovations

- UNDP’s engagement on the issue of depopulation was requested by the President of the Republic in 2019. UNDP and UNFPA have been working together on developing the approach since early 2020.  - The team has sustained engagement with the President's office. The Prime Minister has been briefed in May 2021 and has expressed unequivocal support for taking the work forward and appointed a focal point for the next steps. Individual relevant ministers have been informed of the approach and evolving portfolio through regular meetings that UNDP and UNFPA had with them during the last year, as well as the Prime Minister’s leadership on the issue.

The partnership connected UNDP Colombia’s Accelerator Lab and programme teams with non-traditional financial ecosystem actors, including fintechs, insurers, cooperatives, microfinance institutions and development finance stakeholders. Through FINAGO FEST, UNDP created an experiential space where internal teams co-designed financing solutions and external partners contributed practical insights, feedback and validation.

This collaboration strengthened internal capacities, fostered cross-sector learning, and opened new pathways for innovative Financing for Development portfolios while positioning UNDP as a platform for experimentation and ecosystem building.

links.target: Ministry of ICT Innovation and Youth Affairs
description: Ministry of ICT Innovation and Youth Affairs

We worked with startup communities in remote areas, state led innovation centers and learning centers, vocational training centers and startups.      Lagos Island Connect – We helped surface insights from a needs assessment survey they had conducted on youth and employment in partnership with the Lagos State Government and took part in a collective intelligence session to share these insights and possible next steps.    Start Up South - We worked with Start Up South when engaging the innovation ecosystem in the South-Eastern part of Nigeria. The engagements took place over a 5 day trip to Enugu in November 2021, where we visited a couple of hubs, a university, and the workshops and offices of several actors in that space.     Nigeria Youth SDG Network – We engaged them on several interviews when trying to gain insights on the challenges with youth employment. In addition, they interviewed respondents for a survey on Decent Work carried out by the Industrial Labour Organisation and were able to share insights from this. We also supported the World Youth Skills Day session organized by the Nigerian Youth SDG Network in Lagos, joining the conversation on skills needed by youth employment, post the Covid-19 pandemic.

Pontificia Universidad Catolica del Peru (PUCP, https://www.pucp.edu.pe/): The Lab was involved in the organization of the El Sabor del Futuro event, a weeklong virtual gathering to discuss the future of gastronomy in the country. The Lab also led a workshop with young changemakers which later fed into the Roadmap for the Sustainability of Peruvian Food Systems and Gastronomy.

AGROS (https://www.agros.tech/): Initially we planned to join AGROS in the piloting of their digital identity project for small farmers, which would allow farmers to engage with the value chain in better conditions by having a blockchain-based information system associated to their production and business identity. This pilot was going to take place outside of Lima, so due to travel restrictions in place by the UN Resident Coordinator’s Office we could join them in person; however, the Lab worked with AGROS in the development of the visual identity of the information material and ID card given to the farmers in the project. In the upcoming months the Lab will continue to work with AGROS in the implementation of another similar pilot in Lima to continue to gather insights and understand the challenges on the ground.

We partnered with Bidhee Private Limited to materialize the digital marketing platform called "KrishiCoopBazaar.com". The software engineers from Bidhee helped us to code and prepare the backend of the system as per our requirements.

This platform has been developed for the cooperative markets established by Cooperative Market Development Programme (CMDP), one of the flagship programme between Ministry of Land Management, Cooperatives and Poverty Alleviation and UNDP Nepal. The representatives from the Ministry, project (CMDP) and cooperative markets were involved throughout the process from the beginning of horizon scanning and conceptualization; and every step has been moved ahead after the mutual consensus and approval from the Ministry.

links.target: Local government officials of Fray Mamerto Esquiú
description:
- Argentine Undersecretariat of Administrative Innovation of the Chief of the National Cabinet of Ministers: Early conversations with them gave place to the joint application to a grant to work on the enablers of the action plan given by the RBLAC.

- Local government officials of Fray Mamerto Esquiú, in the province of Catamarca, Argentina: Local officials collaborated closely with the team of consultants put together by the Co_Lab for the implementation of the action.

Within this process we had consultative meetings with the Chamber of Commerce, as well as the consultative team of economists and private sector champions of the DPM for economic affairs – where we presented the design of our methodology for the development of the NDS.

In this process we worked closely with the RCO office in our country, and with other UN agencies. Particularly we collaborated quite closely with the UNHCR team on developing the principles for the methodology that will ensure that no one is left behind from the planning process. We co-wrote one article together with their Innovation Lead and had them on board designing the stages of the process. We had several consultative meetings with our UNCT aimed at identifying the areas where other UN agencies can contribute to this process.

links.target: Ministry of Internal and Foreign Trade
description: Our work on e-commerce and the resilience of the MSMEs was interrupted by elections and the formation of the new government in the Republic of Serbia. In this regard, we collaborated extensively with the Ministry of Trade, Tourism, and Telecommunications during the administration that came before the current one, especially with the state secretary with the mandate for trade and e-commerce. We recognized that our work in the field of eCommerce sits at the intersection of the responsibilities of two ministries in this new government elected in 2022: the Ministry of Internal and Foreign Trade and the Ministry of Information and Telecommunications.
